统计场论第七章

Series expansions

7.1 Low-temperature expansions

Lattice models can also be studied by series expansions. Such expansions start with certain exactly solvable limits, and typically represent perturbations around such limits by graphs on the lattice. High-temperature expansions are described in the next section. Here we describe the low-temperature expansion for the Ising model with a Hamiltonian −βH=K∑⟨i,j⟩σiσj-\beta \mathcal{H}=K \sum_{\langle i, j\rangle} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}−βH=K∑⟨i,j⟩​σi​σj​, on a ddd-dimensional hypercubic lattice. The ground state with K=βJ>0K=\beta J>0K=βJ>0 is ferromagnetic, e.g. with σi=+1\sigma_{i}=+1σi​=+1 for all spins. A series expansion for the partition function is obtained by including low energy excitations around this state. The lowest energy excitation is a single overturned spin. Any of NNN sites can be chosen for this excitation, which has an energy cost of 2K×2d2 K \times 2 d2K×2d, with respect to the ground state. The next lowest energy excitation corresponds to a dimer of negative spins with energy cost of 2K×(4d−2)2 K \times(4 d-2)2K×(4d−2), and a multiplicity of N×dN \times dN×d (there are ddd possible orientations for the dimer). The first few terms in the expansion give

Z=2eNdK[1+Ne−4dK+dNe−4(2d−1)K+N(N−2d−1)2e−8dK+⋯ ]\begin{equation*} Z=2 \mathrm{e}^{N d K}\left[1+N \mathrm{e}^{-4 d K}+d N \mathrm{e}^{-4(2 d-1) K}+\frac{N(N-2 d-1)}{2} \mathrm{e}^{-8 d K}+\cdots\right] \tag{7.1} \end{equation*}Z=2eNdK[1+Ne−4dK+dNe−4(2d−1)K+2N(N−2d−1)​e−8dK+⋯]​(7.1)​

The fourth term comes from flipping two disjoint single spins. The zeroth order term comes from the ground state, which has a two-fold degeneracy. The overall factor of 2 is insignificant in the N→∞N \rightarrow \inftyN→∞ limit, and

Z≃eNdK∑droplets of Θ spins e−2K× boundary of droplet \begin{equation*} Z \simeq \mathrm{e}^{N d K} \sum_{\text {droplets of } \Theta \text { spins }} \mathrm{e}^{-2 K \times \text { boundary of droplet }} \tag{7.2} \end{equation*}Z≃eNdKdroplets of Θ spins ∑​e−2K× boundary of droplet ​(7.2)​

Fig. 7.1 Low-energy excitations as islands of negative spins in the sea of positive spins. The energies and multiplicities on the right refer to a hypercubic lattice in ddd-dimensions.

The free energy per site is obtained from the series,

−βf=ln⁡ZN=dK+1Nln⁡[1+Ne−4dK+dNe−4(2d−1)K+N(N−2d−1)2e−8dK+⋯ ]=dK+e−4dK+de−4(2d−1)K−(2d+1)2e−8dK+⋯\begin{align*} -\beta f=\frac{\ln Z}{N} & =d K+\frac{1}{N} \ln \left[1+N \mathrm{e}^{-4 d K}+d N \mathrm{e}^{-4(2 d-1) K}+\frac{N(N-2 d-1)}{2} \mathrm{e}^{-8 d K}+\cdots\right] \\ & =d K+\mathrm{e}^{-4 d K}+d \mathrm{e}^{-4(2 d-1) K}-\frac{(2 d+1)}{2} \mathrm{e}^{-8 d K}+\cdots \tag{7.3} \end{align*}−βf=NlnZ​​=dK+N1​ln[1+Ne−4dK+dNe−4(2d−1)K+2N(N−2d−1)​e−8dK+⋯]=dK+e−4dK+de−4(2d−1)K−2(2d+1)​e−8dK+⋯​(7.3)​

Note that there is an explicit cancellation of the term proportional to N2N^{2}N2 in the expansion for ZZZ. Such higher NNN dependences result from disconnected diagrams with several disjoint droplets. Extensivity of the free energy insures that these terms are canceled by products of connected graphs. The energy per site is then obtained from

EN=−∂∂β(ln⁡ZN)=−J∂∂K(ln⁡ZN)=−J[d−4de−4dK−4d(2d−1)e−4(2d−1)K+4d(2d+1)e−8dK+⋯ ]\begin{align*} \frac{E}{N} & =-\frac{\partial}{\partial \beta}\left(\frac{\ln Z}{N}\right)=-J \frac{\partial}{\partial K}\left(\frac{\ln Z}{N}\right) \\ & =-J\left[d-4 d \mathrm{e}^{-4 d K}-4 d(2 d-1) \mathrm{e}^{-4(2 d-1) K}+4 d(2 d+1) \mathrm{e}^{-8 d K}+\cdots\right] \tag{7.4} \end{align*}NE​​=−∂β∂​(NlnZ​)=−J∂K∂​(NlnZ​)=−J[d−4de−4dK−4d(2d−1)e−4(2d−1)K+4d(2d+1)e−8dK+⋯]​(7.4)​

and the heat capacity is proportional to

CNkB=1NkB∂E∂T=−K2NJ∂E∂K=K2[16d2e−4dK+16d(2d−1)2e−4(2d−1)K−32d2(2d+1)e−8dK+⋯ ]\begin{align*} \frac{C}{N k_{\mathrm{B}}} & =\frac{1}{N k_{\mathrm{B}}} \frac{\partial E}{\partial T}=-\frac{K^{2}}{N J} \frac{\partial E}{\partial K} \\ & =K^{2}\left[16 d^{2} \mathrm{e}^{-4 d K}+16 d(2 d-1)^{2} \mathrm{e}^{-4(2 d-1) K}-32 d^{2}(2 d+1) \mathrm{e}^{-8 d K}+\cdots\right] \tag{7.5} \end{align*}NkB​C​​=NkB​1​∂T∂E​=−NJK2​∂K∂E​=K2[16d2e−4dK+16d(2d−1)2e−4(2d−1)K−32d2(2d+1)e−8dK+⋯]​(7.5)​

Can such series be used to extract the critical coupling KcK_{c}Kc​, and more importantly, the singularities associated with the disordering transition? Suppose that we have identified a number of terms in a series C=∑ℓ=0∞aℓuℓC=\sum_{\ell=0}^{\infty} a_{\ell} u^{\ell}C=∑ℓ=0∞​aℓ​uℓ. From the expected divergence of the heat capacity, we expect an asymptotic expansion of the form

C≃A(1−uuc)−α=A[1+αucu+α(α+1)2!uc2u2⋯++α(α+1)⋯(α+ℓ−1)ℓ!ucℓuℓ⋯ ].\begin{align*} C \simeq A\left(1-\frac{u}{u_{c}}\right)^{-\alpha} & =A\left[1+\frac{\alpha}{u_{c}} u+\frac{\alpha(\alpha+1)}{2!u_{c}^{2}} u^{2} \cdots+\right. \tag{7.6}\\ & \left.+\frac{\alpha(\alpha+1) \cdots(\alpha+\ell-1)}{\ell!u_{c}^{\ell}} u^{\ell} \cdots\right] . \end{align*}C≃A(1−uc​u​)−α​=A[1+uc​α​u+2!uc2​α(α+1)​u2⋯++ℓ!ucℓ​α(α+1)⋯(α+ℓ−1)​uℓ⋯].​(7.6)​

The above singular form is characterized by the three parameters A,ucA, u_{c}A,uc​, and α\alphaα. We can try to extract these parameters from the calculated coefficients in the series by requiring that they match at large ℓ\ellℓ, i.e. by fitting the ratio of successive terms to

aℓaℓ−1≃(α+ℓ−1ℓuc)=uc−1(1+α−1ℓ).\begin{equation*} \frac{a_{\ell}}{a_{\ell-1}} \simeq\left(\frac{\alpha+\ell-1}{\ell u_{c}}\right)=u_{c}^{-1}\left(1+\frac{\alpha-1}{\ell}\right) . \tag{7.7} \end{equation*}aℓ−1​aℓ​​≃(ℓuc​α+ℓ−1​)=uc−1​(1+ℓα−1​).​(7.7)​

Thus a plot of aℓ/aℓ−1a_{\ell} / a_{\ell-1}aℓ​/aℓ−1​ versus 1/ℓ1 / \ell1/ℓ should be a straight line with intercept uc−1u_{c}^{-1}uc−1​, and slope uc−1(α−1)u_{c}^{-1}(\alpha-1)uc−1​(α−1). Note, however, that adding a finite sum ∑ℓ=0ℓmdℓuℓ\sum_{\ell=0}^{\ell_{m}} d_{\ell} u^{\ell}∑ℓ=0ℓm​​dℓ​uℓ does not change the asymptotic singular form, but essentially renders the first ℓm\ell_{m}ℓm​ terms useless in determining α\alphaα and uc−1u_{c}^{-1}uc−1​. There is thus no a priori guarantee that such a fitting procedure will succeed with a finite number of coefficients. In practice, this procedure works very well and very good estimates of critical exponents in d=3d=3d=3 (e.g. α=0.105±0.007\alpha=0.105 \pm 0.007α=0.105±0.007 ) are obtained in this way by including a rather large number of terms.

The three terms calculated for the heat capacity in Eq. (7.5) have different signs, unlike those of Eq. (7.6). As this continues at higher orders in e−K\mathrm{e}^{-K}e−K, the ratio fitting procedure described above cannot be used directly. The alternation of signs usually signifies singularities in the complex z=e−Kz=\mathrm{e}^{-K}z=e−K plane, closer to the origin than the critical point of interest at real zc=e−Kcz_{c}=\mathrm{e}^{-K_{c}}zc​=e−Kc​. If it is possible to construct a mapping u(z)u(z)u(z) on the complex plane such that the spurious singularities are pushed further away than uc=u(zc)u_{c}=u\left(z_{c}\right)uc​=u(zc​), then the ratio method can be used. In the case of low-temperature series, the choice of u=tanh⁡Ku=\tanh Ku=tanhK achieves this goal. (As we shall demonstrate shortly, tanh⁡K\tanh KtanhK is also the natural variable for the high-temperature expansion.) Quite sophisticated methods, such as Padé approximants, have been developed for analyzing the singular behavior of series.

Low temperature expansions can be similarly constructed for other discrete spin systems, such as the Potts model. For continuous spins, the low energy excitations are Goldstone modes, and the perturbation series cannot be represented in terms of lattice graphs. The low-temperature description in this case starts with the Gaussian treatment of the Goldstone modes, as carried out in the first problem of chapter 3 for the case of the XY model. Further terms in the series involve interactions between such modes, and a corresponding calculation will be performed in the next chapter.

7.2 High-temperature expansions

High-temperature expansions work equally well for discrete and continuous spin systems. The basic idea is to start with independent spins, and expand the partition function in powers of β=(kBT)−1\beta=\left(k_{\mathrm{B}} T\right)^{-1}β=(kB​T)−1, i.e.

Z=tr⁡(e−βH)=tr⁡[1−βH+β2H22−⋯ ],\begin{equation*} Z=\operatorname{tr}\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\beta \mathcal{H}}\right)=\operatorname{tr}\left[1-\beta \mathcal{H}+\frac{\beta^{2} \mathcal{H}^{2}}{2}-\cdots\right], \tag{7.8} \end{equation*}Z=tr(e−βH)=tr[1−βH+2β2H2​−⋯],​(7.8)​

and

ln⁡ZN=ln⁡Z0N−β⟨H⟩0N+β22⟨H2⟩0−⟨H⟩02N−⋯\begin{equation*} \frac{\ln Z}{N}=\frac{\ln Z_{0}}{N}-\beta \frac{\langle\mathcal{H}\rangle_{0}}{N}+\frac{\beta^{2}}{2} \frac{\left\langle\mathcal{H}^{2}\right\rangle_{0}-\langle\mathcal{H}\rangle_{0}^{2}}{N}-\cdots \tag{7.9} \end{equation*}NlnZ​=NlnZ0​​−βN⟨H⟩0​​+2β2​N⟨H2⟩0​−⟨H⟩02​​−⋯​(7.9)​

The averages ⟩0\left\rangle_{0}\right.⟩0​ are calculated over non-interacting spins. For the Ising model, it is more convenient to organize the expansion in powers of tanh⁡K\tanh KtanhK as follows. Since (σiσj)2=1\left(\sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}\right)^{2}=1(σi​σj​)2=1, the Boltzmann factor for each bond can be written as

eKσiσj=eK+e−K2+eK−e−K2σiσj=cosh⁡K(1+tσiσj),\begin{equation*} \mathrm{e}^{K \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}}=\frac{\mathrm{e}^{K}+\mathrm{e}^{-K}}{2}+\frac{\mathrm{e}^{K}-\mathrm{e}^{-K}}{2} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}=\cosh K\left(1+t \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}\right), \tag{7.10} \end{equation*}eKσi​σj​=2eK+e−K​+2eK−e−K​σi​σj​=coshK(1+tσi​σj​),​(7.10)​

Fig. 7.2 A typical term obtained in the expansion of Eq. (7.11).

Fig. 7.3 The first two terms in the expansion of Eq. (7.12) for a square lattice. where t≡tanh⁡Kt \equiv \tanh Kt≡tanhK is a good high-temperature expansion parameter. Applying this transformation to each bond of the lattice results in

Z=∑{σi}eK∑⟨i,j⟩σiσj=(cosh⁡K)number of bonds ∑{σi}⟨i,j⟩∏i(1+tσiσj).\begin{equation*} Z=\sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}} \mathrm{e}^{K \sum\langle i, j\rangle} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}=(\cosh K)^{\text {number of bonds }} \sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}\langle i, j\rangle} \prod_{i}\left(1+t \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}\right) . \tag{7.11} \end{equation*}Z={σi​}∑​eK∑⟨i,j⟩σi​σj​=(coshK)number of bonds {σi​}⟨i,j⟩∑​i∏​(1+tσi​σj​).​(7.11)​

For NbN_{b}Nb​ bonds on the lattice, the above product generates 2Nb2^{N_{b}}2Nb​ terms, which can be represented diagrammatically by drawing a line connecting sites iii and jjj for each factor of tσiσjt \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}tσi​σj​. Note that there can at most be one such line for each lattice bond, which is either empty or occupied. This is a major simplification, and a major advantage for the use of ttt, rather than KKK, as the expansion parameter. Each site now obtains a factor of σipi\sigma_{i}^{p_{i}}σipi​​, where pip_{i}pi​ is the number of occupied bonds emanating from iii. Summing over the two possible values σi=±1\sigma_{i}= \pm 1σi​=±1, gives a factor of 2 if pip_{i}pi​ is even, and 0 if pip_{i}pi​ is odd. Thus, the only graphs that survive the sum have an even number of lines passing through each site. The resulting graphs are collections of closed paths on the lattice, and

Z=2N×(cosh⁡K)Nb∑All closed graphs tnumber of bonds in the graph \begin{equation*} Z=2^{N} \times(\cosh K)^{N_{b}} \sum_{\text {All closed graphs }} t^{\text {number of bonds in the graph }} \tag{7.12} \end{equation*}Z=2N×(coshK)Nb​All closed graphs ∑​tnumber of bonds in the graph ​(7.12)​

For a ddd-dimensional hypercubic lattice, the smallest closed graph is a square of four bonds which has d(d−1)/2d(d-1) / 2d(d−1)/2 possible orientations. As the next graph has six bonds,

Z=2N(cosh⁡K)dN[1+d(d−1)N2t4+d(d−1)(2d−3)t6+⋯ ]\begin{equation*} Z=2^{N}(\cosh K)^{d N}\left[1+\frac{d(d-1) N}{2} t^{4}+d(d-1)(2 d-3) t^{6}+\cdots\right] \tag{7.13} \end{equation*}Z=2N(coshK)dN[1+2d(d−1)N​t4+d(d−1)(2d−3)t6+⋯]​(7.13)​

and

ln⁡ZN=ln⁡2+dln⁡cosh⁡K+d(d−1)2t4+⋯\begin{equation*} \frac{\ln Z}{N}=\ln 2+d \ln \cosh K+\frac{d(d-1)}{2} t^{4}+\cdots \tag{7.14} \end{equation*}NlnZ​=ln2+dlncoshK+2d(d−1)​t4+⋯​(7.14)​

In the following sections we shall employ high-temperature expansions not as a numerical tool, but to establish the following: (a) exact solution of the Ising model in d=1d=1d=1; (b) the duality relating models at low and high temperatures; (c) the validity of the Gaussian model in high dimensions; (d) exact solution of the Ising model in d=2d=2d=2.

7.3 Exact solution of the one-dimensional Ising model

The graphical method provides a rapid way of solving the Ising model at zero field in d=1d=1d=1. We can compare and contrast the solutions on chains with open and closed (periodic) boundary conditions. (1) An open chain of NNN sites has Nb=N−1N_{b}=N-1Nb​=N−1 bonds. It is impossible to draw any closed graphs on such a lattice, and hence

Z=2Ncosh⁡KN−1×1⟹ln⁡ZN=ln⁡[2cosh⁡K]−ln⁡[cosh⁡K]N\begin{equation*} Z=2^{N} \cosh K^{N-1} \times 1 \Longrightarrow \frac{\ln Z}{N}=\ln [2 \cosh K]-\frac{\ln [\cosh K]}{N} \tag{7.15} \end{equation*}Z=2NcoshKN−1×1⟹NlnZ​=ln[2coshK]−Nln[coshK]​​(7.15)​

The same method can also be used to calculate the correlation function ⟨σmσn⟩\left\langle\sigma_{m} \sigma_{n}\right\rangle⟨σm​σn​⟩, since

⟨σmσn⟩=1Z∑⟨σi}eK∑{i,j⟩σiσjσmσn=2N(cosh⁡K)N−1Z∑{σi}σmσn∏⟨i,j⟩(1+tσiσj).\begin{align*} &\left\langle\sigma_{m} \sigma_{n}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{Z} \sum_{\left\langle\sigma_{i}\right\}} \mathrm{e}^{K \sum\{i, j\rangle} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j} \\ & \sigma_{m} \sigma_{n} \tag{7.16}\\ &=\frac{2^{N}(\cosh K)^{N-1}}{Z} \sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}} \sigma_{m} \sigma_{n} \prod_{\langle i, j\rangle}\left(1+t \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}\right) . \end{align*}​⟨σm​σn​⟩=Z1​⟨σi​}∑​eK∑{i,j⟩σi​σj​σm​σn​=Z2N(coshK)N−1​{σi​}∑​σm​σn​⟨i,j⟩∏​(1+tσi​σj​).​(7.16)​

The terms in the numerator involve an additional factor of σmσn\sigma_{m} \sigma_{n}σm​σn​. To get a finite value after summing over σm=±1\sigma_{m}= \pm 1σm​=±1 and σn=±1\sigma_{n}= \pm 1σn​=±1, we have to examine graphs with an odd number of bonds emanating from these external sites. The only such graph for the open chain is one that directly connects these two sites, and results in

⟨σmσn⟩=t∣m−n∣=e−∣m−n∣/ξ, with ξ=−1ln⁡tanh⁡K\begin{equation*} \left\langle\sigma_{m} \sigma_{n}\right\rangle=t^{|m-n|}=\mathrm{e}^{-|m-n| / \xi}, \quad \text { with } \quad \xi=-\frac{1}{\ln \tanh K} \tag{7.17} \end{equation*}⟨σm​σn​⟩=t∣m−n∣=e−∣m−n∣/ξ, with ξ=−lntanhK1​​(7.17)​

These results are in agreement with the RG conclusions of Section 6.4; the correlation length diverges as e2K\mathrm{e}^{2 K}e2K for K→∞K \rightarrow \inftyK→∞, and there is no power law modifying the exponential decay of correlations.

Fig. 7.4 The open chain (top), and the closed chain (bottom). (2) A closed chain has the same number of sites and bonds, NNN. It is now possible to draw a closed graph that circles the whole chain, and

Z=(2cosh⁡K)N[1+tN]=2N(cosh⁡KN+sinh⁡KN)⟹ln⁡ZN=ln⁡(2cosh⁡K)+ln⁡[1+tN]N.\begin{align*} Z=(2 \cosh K)^{N}\left[1+t^{N}\right] & =2^{N}\left(\cosh K^{N}+\sinh K^{N}\right) \\ \Longrightarrow \frac{\ln Z}{N} & =\ln (2 \cosh K)+\frac{\ln \left[1+t^{N}\right]}{N} . \tag{7.1.} \end{align*}Z=(2coshK)N[1+tN]⟹NlnZ​​=2N(coshKN+sinhKN)=ln(2coshK)+Nln[1+tN]​.​(7.1.)​

The difference between the free energies of closed and open chains vanishes in the thermodynamic limit. The correction to the extensive free energy, Nln⁡(2cosh⁡K)N \ln (2 \cosh K)Nln(2coshK), is of the order of 1/N1 / N1/N for the open chain, and can be regarded as the surface free energy. There is no such correction for the closed chain, which has no boundaries; there is instead an exponential term tNt^{N}tN. The correlation function can again be calculated from Eq. (7.16). There are two paths connecting the points mmm and nnn, and

⟨σmσn⟩=t∣m−n∣+tN−∣m−n∣1+tN\begin{equation*} \left\langle\sigma_{m} \sigma_{n}\right\rangle=\frac{t^{|m-n|}+t^{N-|m-n|}}{1+t^{N}} \tag{7.19} \end{equation*}⟨σm​σn​⟩=1+tNt∣m−n∣+tN−∣m−n∣​​(7.19)​

Note that the final answer is symmetric with respect to the two ways of measuring the distance between the two sites mmm and nnn.

7.4 Self-duality in the two-dimensional Ising model

Kramers and Wannier discovered a hidden symmetry that relates the properties of the Ising model on the square lattice at low and high temperatures. One way of obtaining this symmetry is to compare the high and low temperature series expansions of the problem. The low-temperature expansion has the form

Z=e2NK[1+Ne−4×2K+2Ne−6×2K+⋯ ]=e2NK∑Islands of (−) spins e−2K× perimeter of island .\begin{align*} Z & =\mathrm{e}^{2 N K}\left[1+N \mathrm{e}^{-4 \times 2 K}+2 N \mathrm{e}^{-6 \times 2 K}+\cdots\right] \\ & =\mathrm{e}^{2 N K} \sum_{\text {Islands of }(-) \text { spins }} \mathrm{e}^{-2 K \times \text { perimeter of island }} . \tag{7.20} \end{align*}Z​=e2NK[1+Ne−4×2K+2Ne−6×2K+⋯]=e2NKIslands of (−) spins ∑​e−2K× perimeter of island .​(7.20)​

The high-temperature series is

Z=2Ncosh⁡K2N[1+Ntanh⁡K4+2Ntanh⁡K6+⋯ ]=2Ncosh⁡K2N∑graphs with 2 or 4 lines per site tanh⁡Klength of graph .\begin{align*} Z & =2^{N} \cosh K^{2 N}\left[1+N \tanh K^{4}+2 N \tanh K^{6}+\cdots\right] \\ & =2^{N} \cosh K^{2 N} \sum_{\text {graphs with } 2 \text { or } 4 \text { lines per site }} \tanh K^{\text {length of graph } .} \tag{7.21} \end{align*}Z​=2NcoshK2N[1+NtanhK4+2NtanhK6+⋯]=2NcoshK2Ngraphs with 2 or 4 lines per site ∑​tanhKlength of graph .​(7.21)​

As the boundary of any island of spins serves as an acceptable graph (and vice versa), there is a one-to-one correspondence between the two series. Defining a function ggg to indicate the logarithm of the above series, the free energy is given by

ln⁡ZN=2K+g(e−2K)=ln⁡2+2ln⁡cosh⁡K+g(tanh⁡K).\begin{equation*} \frac{\ln Z}{N}=2 K+g\left(\mathrm{e}^{-2 K}\right)=\ln 2+2 \ln \cosh K+g(\tanh K) . \tag{7.22} \end{equation*}NlnZ​=2K+g(e−2K)=ln2+2lncoshK+g(tanhK).​(7.22)​

The arguments of ggg in the above equation are related by the duality condition

e−2K~↔tanh⁡K,⟹K~=D(K)≡−12ln⁡tanh⁡K.\begin{equation*} \mathrm{e}^{-2 \widetilde{K}} \leftrightarrow \tanh K, \Longrightarrow \widetilde{K}=D(K) \equiv-\frac{1}{2} \ln \tanh K . \tag{7.23} \end{equation*}e−2K↔tanhK,⟹K=D(K)≡−21​lntanhK.​(7.23)​

The function ggg (which contains the singular part of the free energy) must have a special symmetry that relates its values for dual arguments. (For example the function f(x)=x/(1+x2)f(x)=x /\left(1+x^{2}\right)f(x)=x/(1+x2) equals f(x−1)f\left(x^{-1}\right)f(x−1), establishing a duality between the arguments at xxx and x−1x^{-1}x−1.) Equation (7.23) has the following properties: (1) Low temperatures are mapped to high temperatures, and vice versa. (2) The mapping connects pairs of points since D(D(K))=KD(D(K))=KD(D(K))=K. This condition is established by using trigonometric identities to show that

sinh⁡2K=2sinh⁡Kcosh⁡K=2tanh⁡Kcosh⁡2K=2tanh⁡K1−tanh⁡2K=2e−2K~1−e−4K~=2e2K~−e−2K~=1sinh⁡2K~.\begin{align*} \sinh 2 K & =2 \sinh K \cosh K=2 \tanh K \cosh ^{2} K \\ & =\frac{2 \tanh K}{1-\tanh ^{2} K}=\frac{2 \mathrm{e}^{-} 2 \widetilde{K}}{1-\mathrm{e}^{-4 \widetilde{K}}}=\frac{2}{\mathrm{e}^{2 \widetilde{K}}-\mathrm{e}^{-2 \widetilde{K}}}=\frac{1}{\sinh 2 \widetilde{K}} . \tag{7.24} \end{align*}sinh2K​=2sinhKcoshK=2tanhKcosh2K=1−tanh2K2tanhK​=1−e−4K2e−2K​=e2K−e−2K2​=sinh2K1​.​(7.24)​

Hence, the dual interactions are symmetrically related by

sinh⁡2K⋅sinh⁡2K~=1\begin{equation*} \sinh 2 K \cdot \sinh 2 \widetilde{K}=1 \tag{7.25} \end{equation*}sinh2K⋅sinh2K=1​(7.25)​

(3) If the function g(K)g(K)g(K) is singular at a point KcK_{c}Kc​, it must also be singular at K~c\widetilde{K}_{c}Kc​. Since the free energy is expected to be analytic everywhere except at the transition, the critical model must be self-dual. At the self-dual point

e−2Kc=tanh⁡Kc=1−e−2Kc1+e−2Kc,\mathrm{e}^{-2 K_{c}}=\tanh K_{c}=\frac{1-\mathrm{e}^{-2 K_{c}}}{1+\mathrm{e}^{-2 K_{c}}},e−2Kc​=tanhKc​=1+e−2Kc​1−e−2Kc​​,

Fig. 7.5 There is a one-to-one correspondence between terms in the high and low temperature series for the Ising model on the square lattice.

Fig. 7.6 The function D(K)D(K)D(K) relating the parameter KKK to its dual value.

Fig. 7.7 The duality function maps pairs of points from high and low temperatures. The self-dual point at KcK_{c}Kc​ maps onto itself.

Clearly the two sums are different, and the 3d3 d3d Ising model is not dual to itself. Is there any other Hamiltonian whose high-temperature series reproduces the low-temperature terms for the 3d3 d3d Ising model? To construct such a model note that: (1) The low-temperature terms have the form e−2K× area \mathrm{e}^{-2 K \times \text { area }}e−2K× area , and the area is the sum of faces covered on the cubic lattice. Thus plaquettes must replace bonds as the building blocks of the required high temperature series. (2) How should these plaquettes be joined together? The number of bonds next to a site can be anywhere from 3 to 12 while there are only two or four faces adjacent to each bond. This suggests "gluing" the plaquettes together by placing spins σ~i=±1\widetilde{\sigma}_{i}= \pm 1σi​=±1 on the bonds of the lattice. (3) By analogy to the Ising model, we can construct a partition function,

Z~=∑{σ~P=±1}∏plaquettes P(1+tanh⁡K~σ~P1σ~P2σ~P3σ~P4)∝∑{σ~i}eK~∑Pσ~P1σ~P2σ~P3σ~P4,\begin{equation*} \widetilde{Z}=\sum_{\left\{\widetilde{\sigma}_{P}= \pm 1\right\}} \prod_{\text {plaquettes } P}\left(1+\tanh \widetilde{K} \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{1} \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{2} \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{3} \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{4}\right) \propto \sum_{\left\{\widetilde{\sigma}_{i}\right\}} \mathrm{e}^{\widetilde{K} \sum P \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{1} \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{2} \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{3} \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{4},} \tag{7.29} \end{equation*}Z={σP​=±1}∑​plaquettes P∏​(1+tanhKσP1​σP2​σP3​σP4​)∝{σi​}∑​eK∑PσP1​σP2​σP3​σP4​,​(7.29)​

where σ~Pi\widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{i}σPi​ are used to denote the four dual spins around each plaquette, and K~\widetilde{K}K is given by Eq. (7.23). This partition function describes a system dual to the original 3d3 d3d Ising model, in the sense of reproducing its low-temperature series. (Some reflection demonstrates that the low-temperature expansion of the above partition function reproduces the high-temperature expansion of the Ising model.) Equation (7.29) describes a Z2Z_{2}Z2​ lattice gauge theory. The general rules for constructing such theories in all dimensions are: (i) place Ising spins σ~i=±1\widetilde{\sigma}_{i}= \pm 1σi​=±1 on the bonds of the lattice; (ii) the Hamiltonian is −βH=K∑all plaquettes Πσ~Pi-\beta \mathcal{H}=K \sum_{\text {all plaquettes }} \Pi \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{i}−βH=K∑all plaquettes ​ΠσPi​. In addition to the global Ising symmetry, σ~i→−σ~i\widetilde{\sigma}_{i} \rightarrow-\widetilde{\sigma}_{i}σi​→−σi​, the Hamiltonian has a local or gauge symmetry. To observe this symmetry, select any site and change the signs of spins on all bonds emanating from it. As in each of the faces adjacent to the chosen site two bond spins change sign, their product, and hence the overall energy, is not changed.

There is a rigorous proof (Elitzur's theorem) that there can be no spontaneous symmetry breaking for Hamiltonians with a local symmetry. The essence of the proof is that even in the presence of a symmetry breaking field hhh, the energy cost of flipping a spin is finite ( 6h6 h6h for the gauge theory on the cubic lattice). Hence the expectation value of spin changes continuously as h→0h \rightarrow 0h→0. (By contrast, the energy cost of a spin flip in the Ising model grows as Nh.) This theorem presents us with the following paradox: Since the three dimensional Ising model undergoes a phase transition, there must be a singularity in its partition function, and also that of its dual. How can there be a singularity in the partition function of the three-dimensional gauge theory if it does not undergo a spontaneous symmetry breaking?

To resolve this contradiction, Wegner suggested the possibility of a phase transition without a local order parameter. The two phases are then distinguished by the asymptotic behavior of correlation functions. The appropriate correlation function must be invariant under the local gauge transformation. For example, the Wilson loop is constructed by selecting a closed path of bonds SSS on the lattice and examining

CS=⟨ Product of σ~ around the loop ⟩=⟨∏i∈Sσ~i⟩.\begin{equation*} C_{S}=\langle\text { Product of } \widetilde{\sigma} \text { around the loop }\rangle=\left\langle\prod_{i \in S} \widetilde{\sigma}_{i}\right\rangle . \tag{7.30} \end{equation*}CS​=⟨ Product of σ around the loop ⟩=⟨i∈S∏​σi​⟩.​(7.30)​

As any gauge transformation changes the signs of two bonds on the loop, their product is unaffected and CSC_{S}CS​ is gauge invariant. Since the Hamiltonian encourages spins of the same sign, this expectation value is always positive. Let us examine the asymptotic dependence of CSC_{S}CS​ on the shape of the loop at high and low temperatures. In a high-temperature expansion, the correlation function is obtained as a sum of all graphs constructed from plaquettes with SSS as a boundary. Each plaquette contributes a factor of tanh⁡K~\tanh \widetilde{K}tanhK, and

CS=1Z∑{σ~i}∏i∈Sσ~ieK∑Pσ~P1σ~P2σ~P3σ~P4=(tanh⁡K~)Area of S[1+O(tanh⁡K~2)]≈exp⁡[−f(tanh⁡K~)×Area⁡ of S]\begin{align*} C_{S} & =\frac{1}{Z} \sum_{\left\{\widetilde{\sigma}_{i}\right\}} \prod_{i \in S} \widetilde{\sigma}_{i} \mathrm{e}^{K \sum_{P} \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{1} \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{2} \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{3} \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{4}} \\ & =(\tanh \widetilde{K})^{\text {Area of } S}\left[1+\mathcal{O}\left(\tanh \widetilde{K}^{2}\right)\right] \approx \exp [-f(\tanh \widetilde{K}) \times \operatorname{Area} \text { of } S] \tag{7.31} \end{align*}CS​​=Z1​{σi​}∑​i∈S∏​σi​eK∑P​σP1​σP2​σP3​σP4​=(tanhK)Area of S[1+O(tanhK2)]≈exp[−f(tanhK)×Area of S]​(7.31)​

The low-temperature expansion starts with the lowest energy configuration. There are in fact NG=2N\mathcal{N}_{G}=2^{N}NG​=2N such ground states related by gauge transformations. The NPN_{P}NP​ plaquette interactions are satisfied in the ground states, and excitations involve creating unsatisfied plaquettes. Since CSC_{S}CS​ is gauge independent, it is sufficient to look at one of the ground states, e.g. the one with σ~i=+1\widetilde{\sigma}_{i}=+1σi​=+1 for all iii. Flipping the sign of any of the 3N3 N3N bonds creates an excitation of energy 8K~8 \widetilde{K}8K with respect to the ground state. Denoting the number of bonds on the perimeter of the Wilson loop by PSP_{S}PS​, we obtain

CS=NGNG⋅eK~NP[1+(3N−PS)e−2K~×4(+1)+(−1)PSe−2K~×4+⋯ ]eK~NP[1+3Ne−2K~×4+⋯ ]=1−2PSe−8K~+⋯≈exp⁡[−2e−8K~PS+⋯ ].\begin{align*} C_{S} & =\frac{\mathcal{N}_{G}}{\mathcal{N}_{G}} \cdot \frac{\mathrm{e}^{\widetilde{K} N_{P}}\left[1+\left(3 N-P_{S}\right) \mathrm{e}^{-2 \widetilde{K} \times 4}(+1)+(-1) P_{S} \mathrm{e}^{-2 \widetilde{K} \times 4}+\cdots\right]}{\mathrm{e}^{\widetilde{K} N_{P}}\left[1+3 N \mathrm{e}^{-2 \widetilde{K} \times 4}+\cdots\right]} \\ & =1-2 P_{S} \mathrm{e}^{-8 \widetilde{K}}+\cdots \tag{7.32}\\ & \approx \exp \left[-2 \mathrm{e}^{-8 \widetilde{K}} P_{S}+\cdots\right] . \end{align*}CS​​=NG​NG​​⋅eKNP​[1+3Ne−2K×4+⋯]eKNP​[1+(3N−PS​)e−2K×4(+1)+(−1)PS​e−2K×4+⋯]​=1−2PS​e−8K+⋯≈exp[−2e−8KPS​+⋯].​(7.32)​

The asymptotic decay of CSC_{S}CS​ is thus different at high and low temperatures. At high temperatures, the decay is controlled by the area of the loop, while at low temperatures it depends on its length. The phase transition marks the change from one type of decay to the other, and by duality has the same singularities in free energy as the Ising model.

The prototype of gauge theories in physics is quantum electrodynamics (QED), with the action

S=∫d4x[ψˉ(−id+eX+m)ψ+14(∂μAν−∂νAμ)2].\begin{equation*} S=\int \mathrm{d}^{4} \mathbf{x}\left[\bar{\psi}(-i d+e \mathbb{X}+m) \psi+\frac{1}{4}\left(\partial_{\mu} A_{\nu}-\partial_{\nu} A_{\mu}\right)^{2}\right] . \tag{7.33} \end{equation*}S=∫d4x[ψˉ​(−id+eX+m)ψ+41​(∂μ​Aν​−∂ν​Aμ​)2].​(7.33)​

The spinor ψ\psiψ is the Dirac field for the electron, and the 4 -vector AAA describes the electromagnetic gauge potential. The phase of ψ\psiψ is not observable, and the action is invariant under the gauge symmetry ψ↦eieϕψ\psi \mapsto \mathrm{e}^{i e \phi} \psiψ↦eieϕψ, and Aμ↦Aμ−∂μϕA_{\mu} \mapsto A_{\mu}-\partial_{\mu} \phiAμ​↦Aμ​−∂μ​ϕ, for any ϕ(x)\phi(\mathbf{x})ϕ(x). The Z2Z_{2}Z2​ lattice gauge theory can be regarded as the Ising analog of QED with the bond spins playing the role of the electromagnetic field. We can introduce a "matter" field by placing spins si=±1s_{i}= \pm 1si​=±1, on the sites of the lattice. The two fields are coupled by the Hamiltonian,

−βH=J∑⟨i,j⟩siσ~ijsj+K∑Pσ~P1σ~P2σ~P3σ~P4,\begin{equation*} -\beta \mathcal{H}=J \sum_{\langle i, j\rangle} s_{i} \widetilde{\sigma}_{i j} s_{j}+K \sum_{P} \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{1} \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{2} \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{3} \widetilde{\sigma}_{P}^{4}, \tag{7.34} \end{equation*}−βH=J⟨i,j⟩∑​si​σij​sj​+KP∑​σP1​σP2​σP3​σP4​,​(7.34)​

where σ~ij\widetilde{\sigma}_{i j}σij​ is the spin on the bond joining iii and jjj. The Hamiltonian has the gauge symmetry si↦(−1)sis_{i} \mapsto(-1) s_{i}si​↦(−1)si​, and σ~i,μ↦−σ~i,μ\widetilde{\sigma}_{i, \mu} \mapsto-\widetilde{\sigma}_{i, \mu}σi,μ​↦−σi,μ​, for all bonds emanating from any site iii.

Regarding one of the lattice directions as time, a Wilson loop is obtained by creating two particles at a distance xxx, propagating them for a time ttt, and then removing them. The probability of such an event is roughly given by CS∼e−U(x)tC_{S} \sim \mathrm{e}^{-U(x) t}CS​∼e−U(x)t, where U(x)U(x)U(x) is the interaction between the two particles. In the high-temperature phase, CSC_{S}CS​ decays with the area of the loop, suggesting U(x)t=U(x) t=U(x)t= f(tanh⁡K~)∣x∣tf(\tanh \widetilde{K})|x| tf(tanhK)∣x∣t. The resulting potential U(x)=f(tanh⁡K~)∣x∣U(x)=f(\tanh \widetilde{K})|x|U(x)=f(tanhK)∣x∣, is like a string that connects the particles together. This is also the potential that describes the confinement of quarks at large distances in quantum chromodynamics. The decay with the length of the loop at low temperatures implies U(x)t≈U(x) t \approxU(x)t≈ g(e−8K~)(∣x∣+t)g\left(\mathrm{e}^{-8 \widetilde{K}}\right)(|x|+t)g(e−8K)(∣x∣+t). For t≫∣x∣t \gg|x|t≫∣x∣ the potential is a constant and the force vanishes. (This asymptotic freedom describes the behavior of quarks at short distances.) The phase transition implies a change in the nature of interactions between particles mediated by the gauge field.

7.6 Summing over phantom loops

The high-temperature series can be approximately summed so as to reproduce the Gaussian model. This correspondence provides a better understanding of why Gaussian behavior is applicable in high dimensions, and also prepares the way for the exact summation of the series in two dimensions in the next section. The high-temperature series for the partition function of the Ising model on a ddd-dimensional hypercubic lattice is obtained from

Z=∑{σi}eK∑⟨ijσiσj=2Ncosh⁡dNK×S,\begin{equation*} Z=\sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}} \mathrm{e}^{K \sum_{\langle i j} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}}=2^{N} \cosh ^{d N} K \times S, \tag{7.35} \end{equation*}Z={σi​}∑​eK∑⟨ij​σi​σj​=2NcoshdNK×S,​(7.35)​

where SSS is the sum over all allowed graphs on the lattice, each weighted by t≡tanh⁡Kt \equiv \tanh Kt≡tanhK raised to the power of the number of bonds in the graph. The allowed graphs have an even number of bonds per site. The simplest graphs have the topology of a single closed loop. There are also graphs composed of disconnected closed loops.

Fig. 7.9 Terms of the high-temperature series organized as sums over loops.

Fig. 7.10 The sum over phantom loops can be exponentiated.

Fig. 7.11 Examples of graphs included in S′S^{\prime}S′ that are not present in SSS.

Keeping in mind the cumulant expansion, we can set

Ξ= sum over contribution of all graphs with one loop, \begin{equation*} \Xi=\text { sum over contribution of all graphs with one loop, } \tag{7.36} \end{equation*}Ξ= sum over contribution of all graphs with one loop, ​(7.36)​

and introduce another sum,

S′=exp⁡(Ξ)=1+Ξ+12(Ξ)2+16(Ξ)3+⋯=1+(1 loop graphs )+(2 loop graphs )+(3 loop graphs )+⋯\begin{align*} S^{\prime} & =\exp (\Xi)=1+\Xi+\frac{1}{2}(\Xi)^{2}+\frac{1}{6}(\Xi)^{3}+\cdots \tag{7.37}\\ & =1+(1 \text { loop graphs })+(2 \text { loop graphs })+(3 \text { loop graphs })+\cdots \end{align*}S′​=exp(Ξ)=1+Ξ+21​(Ξ)2+61​(Ξ)3+⋯=1+(1 loop graphs )+(2 loop graphs )+(3 loop graphs )+⋯​(7.37)​
S′=exp⁡(Ω)=1+(Ω)+12(Ω)2+13!(Ω)3+⋯=1+Ω+3}+3}\begin{aligned} S^{\prime}=\exp (\Omega) & =1+(\Omega)+\frac{1}{2}(\Omega)^{2}+\frac{1}{3!}(\Omega)^{3}+\cdots \\ & =1+\Omega+3\}+3\} \end{aligned}S′=exp(Ω)​=1+(Ω)+21​(Ω)2+3!1​(Ω)3+⋯=1+Ω+3}+3}​

Despite their similarities, the sums SSS and S′S^{\prime}S′ are not identical: There are ambiguities associated with loops that intersect at a single site, which will be discussed more fully in the next section. More importantly, S′S^{\prime}S′ includes additional graphs where a particular bond contributes more than once, while in the original sum SSS, each lattice bond contributes a factor of 1ort1 \mathrm{or} t1ort. This arises because after raising ∃\exists∃ to a power ℓ\ellℓ, a particular bond may contribute up to ℓ\ellℓ times for a factor of tℓt^{\ell}tℓ. In the spirit of the approximation that allows multiple appearances of a bond, we shall also include additional closed paths in Ξ\XiΞ, in which a particular bond is traversed more than once in completing the loop.

Qualitatively, SSS is the partition function of a gas of self-avoiding polymer loops with a monomer fugacity of ttt. The self-avoiding constraint is left out in the partition function S′S^{\prime}S′, which thus corresponds to a gas of phantom polymer loops, which may pass through each other with impunity. Loops of various shapes can be constructed from closed random walks on the lattice, and the corresponding free energy of phantom loops is ln⁡S′=∑\ln S^{\prime}=\sumlnS′=∑ all closed random walks on the lattice ×tlength of walk \times t^{\text {length of walk }}×tlength of walk 

=N∑ℓtℓℓ( number of closed walks of ℓ steps starting and ending at 0). \begin{equation*} =N \sum_{\ell} \frac{t^{\ell}}{\ell}(\text { number of closed walks of } \ell \text { steps starting and ending at } \mathbf{0}) \text {. } \tag{7.38} \end{equation*}=Nℓ∑​ℓtℓ​( number of closed walks of ℓ steps starting and ending at 0). ​(7.38)​

Note that extensivity is guaranteed since (up to boundary effects) the same loop can be started from any point on the lattice. The overall factor of 1/ℓ1 / \ell1/ℓ accounts for the ℓ\ellℓ possible starting points for a loop of length ℓ\ellℓ.

A transfer matrix method can be used to count all possible (phantom) random walks on the lattice. Let us introduce a set of N×NN \times NN×N matrices,

⟨i∣W(ℓ)∣j⟩≡ number of walks from j to i in ℓ steps, \begin{equation*} \langle\mathbf{i}| W(\ell)|\mathbf{j}\rangle \equiv \text { number of walks from } \mathbf{j} \text { to } \mathbf{i} \text { in } \ell \text { steps, } \tag{7.39} \end{equation*}⟨i∣W(ℓ)∣j⟩≡ number of walks from j to i in ℓ steps, ​(7.39)​

in terms of which Eq. (7.38) becomes

ln⁡S′N=12∑ℓtℓℓ⟨0∣W(ℓ)∣0⟩\begin{equation*} \frac{\ln S^{\prime}}{N}=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\ell} \frac{t^{\ell}}{\ell}\langle\mathbf{0}| W(\ell)|\mathbf{0}\rangle \tag{7.40} \end{equation*}NlnS′​=21​ℓ∑​ℓtℓ​⟨0∣W(ℓ)∣0⟩​(7.40)​

The additional factor of 2 arises since the same loop can be traversed by two random walks moving in opposite directions. Similarly, the spin-spin correlation function

⟨σ(0)σ(r)⟩=1Z∑⟨σi⟩σ(0)σ(r)∏⟨ij⟩(1+tσiσj)\begin{equation*} \langle\sigma(\mathbf{0}) \sigma(\mathbf{r})\rangle=\frac{1}{Z} \sum_{\left\langle\sigma_{i}\right\rangle} \sigma(\mathbf{0}) \sigma(\mathbf{r}) \prod_{\langle i j\rangle}\left(1+t \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}\right) \tag{7.41} \end{equation*}⟨σ(0)σ(r)⟩=Z1​⟨σi​⟩∑​σ(0)σ(r)⟨ij⟩∏​(1+tσi​σj​)​(7.41)​

is related to the sum over all paths connecting the points 0\mathbf{0}0 and r\mathbf{r}r on the lattice. In addition to the simple paths that directly connect the two points, there are disconnected graphs that contain additional closed loops. In the same approximation of allowing all intersections between paths, the partition function S′S^{\prime}S′ can be factored out of the numerator and denominator of Eq. (7.41), and

⟨σ(0)σ(r⟩≈∑ℓtℓ⟨r∣W(ℓ)∣0⟩.\begin{equation*} \left\langle\sigma(\mathbf{0}) \sigma(\mathbf{r}\rangle \approx \sum_{\ell} t^{\ell}\langle\mathbf{r}| W(\ell) \mid \mathbf{0}\right\rangle . \tag{7.42} \end{equation*}⟨σ(0)σ(r⟩≈ℓ∑​tℓ⟨r∣W(ℓ)∣0⟩.​(7.42)​

Fig. 7.12 High-temperature series for the two-point correlation function, and its approximation in the phantom path limit.

The counting of phantom paths on a lattice is easily accomplished by taking advantage of their Markovian property. This is the property that each step of a random walk proceeds from its last location and is independent of its previous steps. Hence, the number of walks can be calculated recursively. First, note that any walk from 0\mathbf{0}0 to r\mathbf{r}r in ℓ\ellℓ steps can be accomplished as a walk from 0\mathbf{0}0 to some other point r′\mathbf{r}^{\prime}r′ in ℓ−1\ell-1ℓ−1 steps, followed by a single step from r′\mathbf{r}^{\prime}r′ to r\mathbf{r}r. Summing over all possible locations of the intermediate point leads to

⟨r∣W(ℓ)∣0⟩=∑r′⟨r∣W(1)∣r′⟩×⟨r′∣W(ℓ−1)∣0⟩=⟨r∣TW(ℓ−1)∣0⟩,\begin{align*} \langle\mathbf{r}| W(\ell)|\mathbf{0}\rangle & =\sum_{\mathbf{r}^{\prime}}\langle\mathbf{r}| W(1)\left|\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right\rangle \times\left\langle\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right| W(\ell-1)|\mathbf{0}\rangle \tag{7.43}\\ & =\langle\mathbf{r}| T W(\ell-1)|\mathbf{0}\rangle, \end{align*}⟨r∣W(ℓ)∣0⟩​=r′∑​⟨r∣W(1)∣r′⟩×⟨r′∣W(ℓ−1)∣0⟩=⟨r∣TW(ℓ−1)∣0⟩,​(7.43)​

where the sum corresponds to the product of two matrices, and we have defined T≡W(1)T \equiv W(1)T≡W(1). The recursion process can be continued and

W(ℓ)=TW(ℓ−1)=T2W(ℓ−2)2=⋯=Tℓ.\begin{equation*} W(\ell)=T W(\ell-1)=T^{2} W(\ell-2)^{2}=\cdots=T^{\ell} . \tag{7.44} \end{equation*}W(ℓ)=TW(ℓ−1)=T2W(ℓ−2)2=⋯=Tℓ.​(7.44)​

Fig. 7.13 Recursive calculation of the number of walks on a lattice.

Thus all lattice random walks are generated by the transfer matrix TTT, whose elements are

⟨r∣T∣r′⟩={1 if r and r′ are nearest neighbors 0 otherwise (7.45)\langle\mathbf{r}| T\left|\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right\rangle= \begin{cases}1 & \text { if } \mathbf{r} \text { and } \mathbf{r}^{\prime} \text { are nearest neighbors } \tag{7.45}\\ 0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}⟨r∣T∣r′⟩={10​ if r and r′ are nearest neighbors  otherwise ​(7.45)

(It is also called the adjacency, or connectivity matrix.) For example in d=2d=2d=2,

⟨x,y∣T∣x′,y′⟩=δy,y′(δx,x′+1+δx,x′−1)+δx,x′(δy,y′+1+δy,y′−1),\begin{equation*} \langle x, y| T\left|x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right\rangle=\delta_{y, y^{\prime}}\left(\delta_{x, x^{\prime}+1}+\delta_{x, x^{\prime}-1}\right)+\delta_{x, x^{\prime}}\left(\delta_{y, y^{\prime}+1}+\delta_{y, y^{\prime}-1}\right), \tag{7.46} \end{equation*}⟨x,y∣T∣x′,y′⟩=δy,y′​(δx,x′+1​+δx,x′−1​)+δx,x′​(δy,y′+1​+δy,y′−1​),​(7.46)​

and successive actions of TTT on a walker starting at the origin ∣x,y⟩=δx,0δy,0|x, y\rangle=\delta_{x, 0} \delta_{y, 0}∣x,y⟩=δx,0​δy,0​, generate the patterns

The value at each site is the number of walks ending at that point after ℓ\ellℓ steps. Various properties of random walks can be deduced from diagonalizing the matrix TTT. Due to the translational symmetry of the lattice, this is achieved in the Fourier basis ⟨r∣q⟩=eiq⋅r/N\langle\mathbf{r} \mid \mathbf{q}\rangle=\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{iq} \cdot \mathrm{r}} / \sqrt{N}⟨r∣q⟩=eiq⋅r/N​. For example in d=2d=2d=2, starting from Eq. (7.46), it can be checked that

⟨x,y∣T∣qx,qy⟩=∑x′,y′⟨x,y∣T∣x′,y′⟩⟨x′,y′∣qx,qy⟩=1N[eiqyy(eiqx(x+1)+eiqx(x−1))+eiqxx(eiqy(y+1)+eiqy(y−1))]=1Nei(qxx+qyy)[2cos⁡qx+2cos⁡qy]=T(qx,qy)⟨x,y∣qx,qy⟩.\begin{align*} \langle x, y| T\left|q_{x}, q_{y}\right\rangle & =\sum_{x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}}\langle x, y| T\left|x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right\rangle\left\langle x^{\prime}, y^{\prime} \mid q_{x}, q_{y}\right\rangle \\ & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\left[\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} q_{y} y}\left(\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} q_{x}(x+1)}+\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} q_{x}(x-1)}\right)+\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} q_{x} x}\left(\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} q_{y}(y+1)}+\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} q_{y}(y-1)}\right)\right] \tag{7.47}\\ & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}\left(q_{x} x+q_{y} y\right)}\left[2 \cos q_{x}+2 \cos q_{y}\right]=T\left(q_{x}, q_{y}\right)\left\langle x, y \mid q_{x}, q_{y}\right\rangle . \end{align*}⟨x,y∣T∣qx​,qy​⟩​=x′,y′∑​⟨x,y∣T∣x′,y′⟩⟨x′,y′∣qx​,qy​⟩=N​1​[eiqy​y(eiqx​(x+1)+eiqx​(x−1))+eiqx​x(eiqy​(y+1)+eiqy​(y−1))]=N​1​ei(qx​x+qy​y)[2cosqx​+2cosqy​]=T(qx​,qy​)⟨x,y∣qx​,qy​⟩.​(7.47)​

The generalized eigenvalue for a ddd-dimensional hypercubic lattice is

T(q)=2∑α=1dcos⁡qα\begin{equation*} T(\mathbf{q})=2 \sum_{\alpha=1}^{d} \cos q_{\alpha} \tag{7.48} \end{equation*}T(q)=2α=1∑d​cosqα​​(7.48)​

The correlation function in Eq. (7.42) is now evaluated as

⟨σ(r)σ(0)⟩≈∑ℓ∞tℓ⟨r∣W(ℓ)∣0⟩=∑ℓ∞⟨r∣(tT)ℓ∣0⟩=⟨r∣11−tT∣0⟩=∑q⟨r∣q⟩11−tT(q)⟨q∣0⟩=N∫ ddq(2π)deiq⋅rN11−2t∑α=1dcos⁡qα=∫ddq(2π)deiq⋅r1−2t∑αcos⁡qα.\begin{align*} \langle\sigma(\mathbf{r}) \sigma(\mathbf{0})\rangle & \approx \sum_{\ell}^{\infty} t^{\ell}\langle\mathbf{r}| W(\ell)|\mathbf{0}\rangle=\sum_{\ell}^{\infty}\langle\mathbf{r}|(t T)^{\ell}|\mathbf{0}\rangle \\ & =\langle\mathbf{r}| \frac{1}{1-t T}|\mathbf{0}\rangle=\sum_{\mathbf{q}}\langle\mathbf{r} \mid \mathbf{q}\rangle \frac{1}{1-t T(\mathbf{q})}\langle\mathbf{q} \mid \mathbf{0}\rangle \tag{7.49}\\ & =N \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{\mathrm{e}^{i \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}}}{N} \frac{1}{1-2 t \sum_{\alpha=1}^{d} \cos q_{\alpha}}=\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}}}{1-2 t \sum_{\alpha} \cos q_{\alpha}} . \end{align*}⟨σ(r)σ(0)⟩​≈ℓ∑∞​tℓ⟨r∣W(ℓ)∣0⟩=ℓ∑∞​⟨r∣(tT)ℓ∣0⟩=⟨r∣1−tT1​∣0⟩=q∑​⟨r∣q⟩1−tT(q)1​⟨q∣0⟩=N∫(2π)d ddq​Neiq⋅r​1−2t∑α=1d​cosqα​1​=∫(2π)dddq​1−2t∑α​cosqα​eiq⋅r​.​(7.49)​

For t→0t \rightarrow 0t→0, the shortest path costs least energy and ⟨σ(0)σ(r)⟩∼t∣r∣\langle\sigma(\mathbf{0}) \sigma(\mathbf{r})\rangle \sim t^{|\mathbf{r}|}⟨σ(0)σ(r)⟩∼t∣r∣. As ttt increases, larger paths dominate the sum because they are more numerous (i.e. entropically favored). Eventually, there is a singularity for 1−tT(0)=01-t T(\mathbf{0})=01−tT(0)=0, i.e. at 2d×tc=12 d \times t_{c}=12d×tc​=1, when arbitrarily long paths become important. For t<tct<t_{c}t<tc​, the partition function is dominated by small loops, and a polymer connecting two far away points is stretched by its line tension. When the fugacity exceeds tct_{c}tc​, the line tension vanishes and loops of arbitrary size are generated. Clearly the neglect of intersections (which stabilizes the system at a finite density) is no longer justified in this limit. This transition is the manifestation of Ising ordering in the language of paths representing the high-temperature series. On approaching the transition from the high-temperature side, the sums are dominated by very long paths. Accordingly, the denominator of Eq. (7.49) can be expanded for small q\mathbf{q}q as

1−tT(q)=1−2t∑α=1dcos⁡qα≃(1−2dt)+tq2+O(q4)≈tc(ξ−2+q2+O(q4))\begin{align*} 1-t T(\mathbf{q}) & =1-2 t \sum_{\alpha=1}^{d} \cos q_{\alpha} \simeq(1-2 d t)+t q^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(q^{4}\right) \\ & \approx t_{c}\left(\xi^{-2}+q^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(q^{4}\right)\right) \tag{7.50} \end{align*}1−tT(q)​=1−2tα=1∑d​cosqα​≃(1−2dt)+tq2+O(q4)≈tc​(ξ−2+q2+O(q4))​(7.50)​

where

ξ≡(1−2dttc)−1/2\begin{equation*} \xi \equiv\left(\frac{1-2 d t}{t_{c}}\right)^{-1 / 2} \tag{7.51} \end{equation*}ξ≡(tc​1−2dt​)−1/2​(7.51)​

The resulting correlation functions,

⟨σ(0)σ(r)⟩∝∫ddq(2π)deiq⋅rq2+ξ−2,\langle\sigma(\mathbf{0}) \sigma(\mathbf{r})\rangle \propto \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{r}}}{q^{2}+\xi^{-2}},⟨σ(0)σ(r)⟩∝∫(2π)dddq​q2+ξ−2eiq⋅r​,

are identical to those obtained from the Gaussian model, and (Sec. 3.2)

⟨σ(0)σ(r)⟩∝{1rd−2 for r<ξ(η=0)e−r/ξr(d−1)/2 for r>ξ.(7.52)\langle\sigma(\mathbf{0}) \sigma(\mathbf{r})\rangle \propto \begin{cases}\frac{1}{r^{d-2}} & \text { for } r<\xi \quad(\eta=0) \tag{7.52}\\ \frac{\mathrm{e}^{-r / \xi}}{r^{(d-1) / 2}} & \text { for } r>\xi .\end{cases}⟨σ(0)σ(r)⟩∝{rd−21​r(d−1)/2e−r/ξ​​ for r<ξ(η=0) for r>ξ.​(7.52)

The correlation length in Eq. (7.51) diverges as ξ∼(tc−t)−1/2\xi \sim\left(t_{c}-t\right)^{-1 / 2}ξ∼(tc​−t)−1/2, i.e. with the Gaussian exponent of ν=1/2\nu=1 / 2ν=1/2.

We can also calculate the free energy in Eq. (7.40) as

ln⁡S′N=12∑ℓ∞tℓℓ⟨0∣W(ℓ)∣0⟩=12⟨0∣∑ℓ∞tℓTℓℓ∣0⟩=−12⟨0∣ln⁡(1−tT)∣0⟩=−N2∫ ddq(2π)d⟨0∣q⟩ln⁡(1−tT(q))⟨q∣0⟩=−12∫ ddq(2π)dln⁡(1−2t∑α=1dcos⁡qα).\begin{align*} \frac{\ln S^{\prime}}{N} & =\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\ell}^{\infty} \frac{t^{\ell}}{\ell}\langle\mathbf{0}| W(\ell)|\mathbf{0}\rangle=\frac{1}{2}\langle\mathbf{0}| \sum_{\ell}^{\infty} \frac{t^{\ell} T^{\ell}}{\ell}|\mathbf{0}\rangle \\ & =-\frac{1}{2}\langle\mathbf{0}| \ln (1-t T)|\mathbf{0}\rangle=-\frac{N}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}}\langle\mathbf{0} \mid \mathbf{q}\rangle \ln (1-t T(\mathbf{q}))\langle\mathbf{q} \mid \mathbf{0}\rangle \\ & =-\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \ln \left(1-2 t \sum_{\alpha=1}^{d} \cos q_{\alpha}\right) . \tag{7.53} \end{align*}NlnS′​​=21​ℓ∑∞​ℓtℓ​⟨0∣W(ℓ)∣0⟩=21​⟨0∣ℓ∑∞​ℓtℓTℓ​∣0⟩=−21​⟨0∣ln(1−tT)∣0⟩=−2N​∫(2π)d ddq​⟨0∣q⟩ln(1−tT(q))⟨q∣0⟩=−21​∫(2π)d ddq​ln(1−2tα=1∑d​cosqα​).​(7.53)​

In the vicinity of the critical point at tc=1/(2d)t_{c}=1 /(2 d)tc​=1/(2d), the argument of the logarithm is proportional to (q2+ξ−2)\left(q^{2}+\xi^{-2}\right)(q2+ξ−2) from Eq. (7.50). This is precisely as in the Gaussian model, and as discussed in Sec. 4.6 the singular part of the free energy scales as

fsing ∝ξ−d∝(tc−t)d/2\begin{equation*} f_{\text {sing }} \propto \xi^{-d} \propto\left(t_{c}-t\right)^{d / 2} \tag{7.54} \end{equation*}fsing ​∝ξ−d∝(tc​−t)d/2​(7.54)​

The singular part of the heat capacity, obtained after taking two derivatives, is governed by the exponent α=2−d/2\alpha=2-d / 2α=2−d/2. Note that in evaluating the sums appearing in Eqs. (7.49) and (7.53), the lower limit for ℓ\ellℓ is not treated very carefully. The series in Eq. (7.49) is assumed to start from ℓ=0\ell=0ℓ=0, and that of Eq. (7.53) from ℓ=1\ell=1ℓ=1. In fact the first few terms of both series may be zero because the number of steps is not sufficient to reach 0\mathbf{0}0 from r\mathbf{r}r, or to form a closed loop. This is not a serious omission, in that the singular behavior of a series is not affected by its first few terms. Treating the first few terms differently can only add analytic corrections to the singular forms calculated in Eqs. (7.49) and (7.53).

The equivalence of these results to the Gaussian model is a manifestation of field-particle duality. In a field theoretical description, (imaginary) time appears as an additional dimension, and the two-point correlations describe the probability of propagating a particle from one point in space-time to another. In a wave description, this probability is calculated by evolving the wave function using the Schrödinger equation. Alternatively, the probability can be calculated as the sum over all (Feynman) paths connecting the two points, each path weighted with the correct action. The second sum is similar to the above calculation of ⟨σ(r)σ(0)⟩\langle\sigma(\mathbf{r}) \sigma(\mathbf{0})\rangle⟨σ(r)σ(0)⟩.

This approach provides an interesting geometrical interpretation of the phase transition. The establishment of long-range order implies that all parts of the system have selected the same state. This information is carried by the bonds connecting nearest neighbors, and can be passed from the origin to a point r\mathbf{r}r, through all paths connecting these two points. The fugacity ttt is a measure of the reliability of information transfer between neighboring sites. Along a one-dimensional chain, unless t=1t=1t=1, the transferred information decays at large distances and it is impossible to establish long-range order. In higher dimensions there are many more paths, and by accumulating the information from all paths it is possible to establish order at tc<1t_{c}<1tc​<1. Since the number of paths of length ℓ\ellℓ grows as (2d)ℓ(2 d)^{\ell}(2d)ℓ while their information content decays as tℓt^{\ell}tℓ, the transition occurs at tc=1/(2d)t_{c}=1 /(2 d)tc​=1/(2d). (A better approximation is obtained by including some of the constraints by noting that the random walk cannot back track. In this case the number of walks grows as (2d−1)ℓ(2 d-1)^{\ell}(2d−1)ℓ.) The total information from paths of length ℓ\ellℓ is weighted by (2dt)ℓ(2 d t)^{\ell}(2dt)ℓ, and decays exponentially for t<tct<t_{c}t<tc​. The characteristic path length, ℓˉ=−1/ln⁡(2dt)\bar{\ell}=-1 / \ln (2 d t)ℓˉ=−1/ln(2dt), diverges as (tc−t)−1\left(t_{c}-t\right)^{-1}(tc​−t)−1 on approaching the transition. For paths of size ℓ≪ℓˉ\ell \ll \bar{\ell}ℓ≪ℓˉ there is very good information transfer. Such paths execute random walks on the lattice and cover a distance ξ≈ℓˉ1/2\xi \approx \bar{\ell}^{1 / 2}ξ≈ℓˉ1/2. The divergence of ν\nuν with an exponent of 1/21 / 21/2 is thus a consequence of the random walk nature of the paths.

Why does the classical picture fail for d≤4d \leq 4d≤4 ? Let us focus on the dominant paths close to the phase transition. Is it justified to ignore the intersections of such paths? Random walks can be regarded as geometrical entities of fractal (Hausdorf) dimension df=2d_{f}=2df​=2. This follows from the general definition of dimension relating the mass and extent of an object by M∝RdfM \propto R^{d_{f}}M∝Rdf​, and the observation that the size of a random walk (R∝ξ)(R \propto \xi)(R∝ξ) is the square root of its length (M∝ℓ)(M \propto \ell)(M∝ℓ). Two geometrical entities of dimensions d1d_{1}d1​ and d2d_{2}d2​ will generally intersect in ddd-dimensional space if d1+d2≥dd_{1}+d_{2} \geq dd1​+d2​≥d. Thus our random walkers are unlikely to intersect in d≥du=2+2=4d \geq d_{u}=2+2=4d≥du​=2+2=4, and the above (Gaussian) results obtained by neglecting the intersections are asymptotically valid. Below the upper critical dimension of 4 , random walks have frequent encounters and their intersections must be treated correctly. The diagrams obtained in the perturbative calculation of the propagator with um4u m^{4}um4 correspond precisely to taking into account the intersections of paths. (Each factor of uuu corresponds to one intersection.) It is now clear that the constraint of self-avoidance will swell the paths beyond their random walk size leading to an increase in the exponent ν\nuν. Below the transition the length of paths grows without bound and the self-avoiding constraint is necessary to ensure the stability of the system.

As demonstrated in the problem section, the loop expansion is easily generalized to nnn-component spins. The only difference is that each closed loop now contributes a factor of nnn. In the phantom limit, where intersections are ignored, the free energy (Eq. 7.53) is simply multiplied by nnn, while the correlation function is left unchanged (precisely as in the Gaussian model). Corrections due to intersections, which modify critical behavior in d<4d<4d<4, now depend on nnn. For example, in correcting the two point correlation function, we have to subtract contributions from the self-intersections of the random walk, as well as from contacts with loops (which have a fugacity of nnn ). The correspondence with the perturbative series of the propagator with a nonlinearity u(m⃗⋅m⃗)2u(\vec{m} \cdot \vec{m})^{2}u(m⋅m)2 is again apparent.

Fig. 7.14 The single high temperature graph on the left with an intersection point can be generated by the three random walks on the right.

Fig. 7.15 Examples of random walks with multiple crossings of a bond, which have no counterpart in the high-temperature series.

7.7 Exact free energy of the square lattice Ising model

As indicated in Eq. (7.35), the Ising partition function is related to a sum SSS, over collections of paths on the lattice. The allowed graphs for a square lattice have two or four bonds per site. Each bond can appear only once in each graph, contributing a factor of t≡tanh⁡Kt \equiv \tanh Kt≡tanhK. While it is tempting to replace SSS with the exactly calculable sum S′S^{\prime}S′, of all phantom loops of random walks on the lattice, this leads to an overestimation of SSS. The differences between the two sums arise from intersections of random walks, and can be divided into two categories: (a) There is an over-counting of graphs which intersect at a site, i.e. with four bonds through a point. Consider a graph composed of two loops meeting at a site. Since a walker entering the intersection has three choices, this graph can be represented by three distinct random walks. One choice leads to two disconnected loops; the other two are single loops with or without a self-crossing in the walker's path. (b) The independent random walkers in S′S^{\prime}S′ may go through a particular lattice bond more than once.

Including these constraints amounts to introducing interactions between paths. The resulting interacting random walkers are non-Markovian, as each step is no longer independent of previous ones and of other walkers. While such interacting walks are not in general amenable to exact treatment, in two dimensions an interesting topological property allows us to make the following assertion:

S=∑ collections of loops of random walks with no U-turns ×tnumber of bonds ×(−1)number of crossings. \begin{align*} S= & \sum \text { collections of loops of random walks with no U-turns } \\ & \times t^{\text {number of bonds }} \times(-1)^{\text {number of crossings. }} \tag{7.55} \end{align*}S=​∑ collections of loops of random walks with no U-turns ×tnumber of bonds ×(−1)number of crossings. ​(7.55)​

The negative signs for some terms reduce the overestimate and render the exact sum.

Justification We shall deal in turn with the two problems mentioned above. (a) Consider a graph with many intersections and focus on a particular one. A walker must enter and leave such an intersection twice. This can be done in three ways, only one of which involves the path of the walker crossing itself (when the walker proceeds straight through the intersection twice). This configuration carries an additional factor of (−1)(-1)(−1) according to Eq. (7.55). Thus, independent of other crossings, these three configurations sum up to contribute a factor of 1 . By repeating this reasoning at each intersection, we see that the over-counting problem is removed and the sum over all possible ways of tracing the graph leads to the correct factor of one. (b) Consider a bond that is crossed by two walkers (or twice by the same walker). We can imagine the bond as an avenue with two sides. For each configuration in which the two paths enter and leave on the same side of the avenue, there is another one in which the paths go to the opposite side. The latter involves a crossing of paths and hence carries a minus sign with respect to the former. The two possibilities thus cancel out! The reasoning can be generalized to multiple passes through any bond. The only exception is when the double bond is created as a result of a U-turn. This is why such backward steps are explicitly excluded from Eq. (7.55).

Fig. 7.16 The intersection point can be traversed in three ways, with the last carrying a relative factor of (-1).

Fig. 7.17 The two ways of traversing a doubly crossed bond carry opposite factors and cancel out.

Fig. 7.18 Two examples of canceling random walk loops.

Let us label random walkers with no U-turns, and weighted by (−1)number of crossings (-1)^{\text {number of crossings }}(−1)number of crossings , as RW∗\mathrm{RW}^{*}RW∗. Then as in Eq. (7.37) the terms in SSS can be organized as

S=∑(RW∗ s with 1 loop )+∑(RW∗ s with 2 loops )+∑(RW∗ s with 3 loops )+⋯=exp⁡[∑(RW∗ s with 1 loop )]\begin{align*} S & =\sum\left(\mathrm{RW}^{*} \mathrm{~s} \text { with } 1 \text { loop }\right)+\sum\left(\mathrm{RW}^{*} \mathrm{~s} \text { with } 2 \text { loops }\right)+\sum\left(\mathrm{RW}^{*} \mathrm{~s} \text { with } 3 \text { loops }\right)+\cdots \\ & =\exp \left[\sum\left(\mathrm{RW}^{*} \mathrm{~s} \text { with } 1 \text { loop }\right)\right] \tag{7.56} \end{align*}S​=∑(RW∗ s with 1 loop )+∑(RW∗ s with 2 loops )+∑(RW∗ s with 3 loops )+⋯=exp[∑(RW∗ s with 1 loop )]​(7.56)​

The exponentiation of the sum is justified, since the only interaction between RW∗ s\mathrm{RW}^{*} \mathrm{~s}RW∗ s is the sign related to their crossings. As two RW* loops always cross an even number of times, this is equivalent to no interaction at all. Using Eq. (7.35), the full Ising free energy is calculated as

ln⁡Z=Nln⁡2+2Nln⁡cosh⁡K+∑(RW∗ s with 1 loop ×t# of bonds )\begin{equation*} \ln Z=N \ln 2+2 N \ln \cosh K+\sum\left(\mathrm{RW}^{*} \mathrm{~s} \text { with } 1 \text { loop } \times t^{\# \text { of bonds }}\right) \tag{7.57} \end{equation*}lnZ=Nln2+2NlncoshK+∑(RW∗ s with 1 loop ×t# of bonds )​(7.57)​

Organizing the sum in terms of the number of bonds, and taking advantage of the translational symmetry of the lattice (up to corrections due to boundaries),

ln⁡ZN=ln⁡(2cosh⁡2K)+∑ℓ∞tℓℓ⟨0∣W∗(ℓ)∣0⟩\begin{equation*} \frac{\ln Z}{N}=\ln \left(2 \cosh ^{2} K\right)+\sum_{\ell}^{\infty} \frac{t^{\ell}}{\ell}\langle\mathbf{0}| W^{*}(\ell)|\mathbf{0}\rangle \tag{7.58} \end{equation*}NlnZ​=ln(2cosh2K)+ℓ∑∞​ℓtℓ​⟨0∣W∗(ℓ)∣0⟩​(7.58)​

where

⟨0∣W∗(ℓ)∣0⟩= number of closed loops of ℓ steps, with no U-turns,  from 0 to 0×(−1)# of crossings \begin{align*} \langle\mathbf{0}| W^{*}(\ell)|\mathbf{0}\rangle= & \text { number of closed loops of } \ell \text { steps, with no U-turns, } \\ & \text { from } \mathbf{0} \text { to } \mathbf{0} \times(-1)^{\#} \text { of crossings } \tag{7.59} \end{align*}⟨0∣W∗(ℓ)∣0⟩=​ number of closed loops of ℓ steps, with no U-turns,  from 0 to 0×(−1)# of crossings ​(7.59)​

The absence of U-turns, a local constraint, does not complicate the counting of loops. On the other hand, the number of crossings is a function of the complete configuration of the loop and is a non-Markovian property. Fortunately, in two dimensions it is possible to obtain the parity of the number of crossings from local considerations. The first step is to construct the loops from directed random walks, indicated by placing an arrow along the direction that the path is traversed. Since any loop can be traversed in two directions,

⟨0∣W∗(ℓ)∣0⟩=12∑ directed RW∗ loops of ℓ steps, no U-turns,  from 0 to 0×(−1)nc\begin{align*} \langle\mathbf{0}| W^{*}(\ell)|\mathbf{0}\rangle= & \frac{1}{2} \sum \text { directed } \mathrm{RW}^{*} \text { loops of } \ell \text { steps, no U-turns, } \\ & \text { from } \mathbf{0} \text { to } \mathbf{0} \times(-1)^{n_{c}} \tag{7.60} \end{align*}⟨0∣W∗(ℓ)∣0⟩=​21​∑ directed RW∗ loops of ℓ steps, no U-turns,  from 0 to 0×(−1)nc​​(7.60)​

where ncn_{c}nc​ is the number of self-crossings of the loop. We can now take advantage of the following topological result:

Whitney's theorem: The number of self-crossings of a planar loop is related to the total angle Θ\ThetaΘ, through which the tangent vector turns in going around the loop by

(nc) mod 2=(1+Θ2π) mod 2\begin{equation*} \left(n_{c}\right)_{\bmod 2}=\left(1+\frac{\Theta}{2 \pi}\right)_{\bmod 2} \tag{7.61} \end{equation*}(nc​)mod2​=(1+2πΘ​)mod2​​(7.61)​

This theorem can be checked by a few examples. A single loop corresponds to Θ=±2π\Theta= \pm 2 \piΘ=±2π, while a single intersection results in Θ=0\Theta=0Θ=0. (a) (b)

Fig. 7.19 Illustration of Whitney's theorem: The angle of the tangent vector on traversing each closed loop is plotted below it. The net angle can be related to the number of crossings.

Since the total angle Θ\ThetaΘ is the sum of the angles through which the walker turns at each step, the parity of crossings can be obtained using local information alone as

(−1)nc=eiπnc=exp⁡[iπ(1+Θ2π)]=−ei2∑j=1ℓθj\begin{equation*} (-1)^{n_{c}}=\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \pi n_{c}}=\exp \left[\mathrm{i} \pi\left(1+\frac{\Theta}{2 \pi}\right)\right]=-\mathrm{e}^{\frac{i}{2} \sum_{j=1}^{\ell} \theta_{j}} \tag{7.62} \end{equation*}(−1)nc​=eiπnc​=exp[iπ(1+2πΘ​)]=−e2i​∑j=1ℓ​θj​​(7.62)​

where θj\theta_{j}θj​ is the angle through which the walker turns on the jjj th step, leading to ⟨0∣W∗(ℓ)∣0⟩=−12∑\langle\mathbf{0}| W^{*}(\ell)|\mathbf{0}\rangle=-\frac{1}{2} \sum⟨0∣W∗(ℓ)∣0⟩=−21​∑ directed RW∗\mathrm{RW}^{*}RW∗ loops of ℓ\ellℓ steps, with no U-turns, from 0\mathbf{0}0 to 0×exp⁡(i2∑\mathbf{0} \times \exp \left(\frac{i}{2} \sum\right.0×exp(2i​∑ local change of angle by the tangent vector ))).

The angle turned can be calculated at each site, if we keep track of the directions of arrival and departure of the path. To this end, we introduce a label

Fig. 7.20 Labeling directions out of a site. μ\muμ for the four directions going out of each site, e.g. μ=1\mu=1μ=1 for right, μ=2\mu=2μ=2 for up, μ=3\mu=3μ=3 for left, and μ=4\mu=4μ=4 for down. We next introduce a set of 4N×4N4 N \times 4 N4N×4N matrices generalizing Eq. (7.39) as ⟨x2y2,μ2∣W∗(ℓ)∣x1y1,μ1⟩=∑\left\langle x_{2} y_{2}, \mu_{2}\right| W^{*}(\ell)\left|x_{1} y_{1}, \mu_{1}\right\rangle=\sum⟨x2​y2​,μ2​∣W∗(ℓ)∣x1​y1​,μ1​⟩=∑ directed random walks of ℓ\ellℓ steps, with no UUU-turns, departing (x1,y1)\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)(x1​,y1​) along μ1\mu_{1}μ1​, proceeding along μ2\mu_{2}μ2​ after reaching (x2,y2)×ei2∑j=1ℓθj\left(x_{2}, y_{2}\right) \times \mathrm{e}^{\frac{i}{2} \sum_{j=1}^{\ell} \theta_{j}}(x2​,y2​)×e2i​∑j=1ℓ​θj​.

Thus μ2\mu_{2}μ2​ specifies a direction taken after the walker reaches its destination. It serves to exclude some paths (e.g. arriving along −μ2-\mu_{2}−μ2​ ), and leads to an additional phase.

As in Eq. (7.43), due to their Markovian property, these matrices can be calculated recursively as

⟨x′y′,μ′∣W∗(ℓ)∣xy,μ⟩=∑x′′y′′,μ′′⟨x′y′,μ′∣T∗∣x′′y′′,μ′′⟩⟨x′′y′′,μ′′∣W∗(ℓ−1)∣xy,μ⟩=⟨x′y′,μ′∣T∗W∗(ℓ−1)∣xy,μ⟩=⟨x′y′,μ′∣T∗ℓ∣xy,μ⟩\begin{align*} \left\langle x^{\prime} y^{\prime}, \mu^{\prime}\right| W^{*}(\ell)|x y, \mu\rangle & =\sum_{x^{\prime \prime} y^{\prime \prime}, \mu^{\prime \prime}}\left\langle x^{\prime} y^{\prime}, \mu^{\prime}\right| T^{*}\left|x^{\prime \prime} y^{\prime \prime}, \mu^{\prime \prime}\right\rangle\left\langle x^{\prime \prime} y^{\prime \prime}, \mu^{\prime \prime}\right| W^{*}(\ell-1)|x y, \mu\rangle \\ & =\left\langle x^{\prime} y^{\prime}, \mu^{\prime}\right| T^{*} W^{*}(\ell-1)|x y, \mu\rangle=\left\langle x^{\prime} y^{\prime}, \mu^{\prime}\right| T^{* \ell}|x y, \mu\rangle \tag{7.65} \end{align*}⟨x′y′,μ′∣W∗(ℓ)∣xy,μ⟩​=x′′y′′,μ′′∑​⟨x′y′,μ′∣T∗∣x′′y′′,μ′′⟩⟨x′′y′′,μ′′∣W∗(ℓ−1)∣xy,μ⟩=⟨x′y′,μ′∣T∗W∗(ℓ−1)∣xy,μ⟩=⟨x′y′,μ′∣T∗ℓ∣xy,μ⟩​(7.65)​

where T∗≡W∗(1)T^{*} \equiv W^{*}(1)T∗≡W∗(1) describes one step of the walk. The direction of arrival uniquely determines the nearest neighbor from which the walker departed, and the angle between the two directions fixes the phase of the matrix element. We can thus generalize Eq. (7.46) to a 4×44 \times 44×4 matrix that keeps track of both connectivity and phase between pairs of sites. The steps taken can be represented diagrammatically as

T∗=[→→⇄↓↑↑←↑↓↑↑←⇄↑←←↓↓↓↑↓↓],(7.66)T^{*}=\left[\begin{array}{cccc} \rightarrow & \rightarrow & \rightleftarrows & \downarrow \tag{7.66}\\ \uparrow & \uparrow & \leftarrow & \uparrow \downarrow \\ & \uparrow & \uparrow & \leftarrow \\ \rightleftarrows & \uparrow \leftarrow & \leftarrow & \downarrow \\ \downarrow & \downarrow \uparrow & \downarrow & \downarrow \end{array}\right],T∗=​→↑⇄↓​→↑↑↑←↓↑​⇄←↑←↓​↓↑↓←↓↓​​,(7.66)

and correspond to the matrix

⟨x′y′∣T∗∣xy⟩=[⟨x′,y′∣x+1,y⟩⟨x′,y′∣x+1,y⟩eiπ40⟨x′,y′∣x+1,y⟩e−iπ4⟨x′,y′∣x,y+1⟩e−iπ4⟨x′,y′∣x,y+1⟩⟨x′,y′∣x,y+1⟩eiπ400⟨x′,y′∣x−1,y⟩e−iπ4⟨x′,y′∣x−1,y⟩⟨x′,y′∣x−1,y⟩eiπ4⟨x′,y′∣x,y−1⟩eiπ40⟨x′,y′∣x,y−1⟩e−iπ4⟨x′,y′∣x,y−1⟩],\begin{align*} & \left\langle x^{\prime} y^{\prime}\right| T^{*}|x y\rangle= \\ & {\left[\begin{array}{cccc} \left\langle x^{\prime}, y^{\prime} \mid x+1, y\right\rangle & \left\langle x^{\prime}, y^{\prime} \mid x+1, y\right\rangle \mathrm{e}^{\frac{i \pi}{4}} & 0 & \left\langle x^{\prime}, y^{\prime} \mid x+1, y\right\rangle \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{i \pi}{4}} \\ \left\langle x^{\prime}, y^{\prime} \mid x, y+1\right\rangle \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{i \pi}{4}} & \left\langle x^{\prime}, y^{\prime} \mid x, y+1\right\rangle & \left\langle x^{\prime}, y^{\prime} \mid x, y+1\right\rangle \mathrm{e}^{\frac{i \pi}{4}} & 0 \\ 0 & \left\langle x^{\prime}, y^{\prime} \mid x-1, y\right\rangle \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{i \pi}{4}} & \left\langle x^{\prime}, y^{\prime} \mid x-1, y\right\rangle & \left\langle x^{\prime}, y^{\prime} \mid x-1, y\right\rangle \mathrm{e}^{\frac{i \pi}{4}} \\ \left\langle x^{\prime}, y^{\prime} \mid x, y-1\right\rangle \mathrm{e}^{\frac{i \pi}{4}} & 0 & \left\langle x^{\prime}, y^{\prime} \mid x, y-1\right\rangle \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{i \pi}{4}} & \left\langle x^{\prime}, y^{\prime} \mid x, y-1\right\rangle \end{array}\right],} \tag{7.67} \end{align*}​⟨x′y′∣T∗∣xy⟩=​⟨x′,y′∣x+1,y⟩⟨x′,y′∣x,y+1⟩e−4iπ​0⟨x′,y′∣x,y−1⟩e4iπ​​⟨x′,y′∣x+1,y⟩e4iπ​⟨x′,y′∣x,y+1⟩⟨x′,y′∣x−1,y⟩e−4iπ​0​0⟨x′,y′∣x,y+1⟩e4iπ​⟨x′,y′∣x−1,y⟩⟨x′,y′∣x,y−1⟩e−4iπ​​⟨x′,y′∣x+1,y⟩e−4iπ​0⟨x′,y′∣x−1,y⟩e4iπ​⟨x′,y′∣x,y−1⟩​​,​(7.67)​

where ⟨x,y∣x′,y′⟩≡δx,x′δy,y′\left\langle x, y \mid x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right\rangle \equiv \delta_{x, x^{\prime}} \delta_{y, y^{\prime}}⟨x,y∣x′,y′⟩≡δx,x′​δy,y′​. Because of its translational symmetry, the 4N×4N4 N \times 4 N4N×4N matrix takes a block diagonal form in the Fourier basis, ⟨xy∣qxqy⟩=ei(qxx+qyy)/N\left\langle x y \mid q_{x} q_{y}\right\rangle=\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}\left(q_{x} x+q_{y} y\right)} / \sqrt{N}⟨xy∣qx​qy​⟩=ei(qx​x+qy​y)/N​, i.e.

∑xy⟨x′y′,μ′∣T∗∣xy,μ⟩⟨xy∣qxqy⟩=⟨μ′∣T∗(q)∣μ⟩⟨x′y′∣qxqy⟩\begin{equation*} \sum_{x y}\left\langle x^{\prime} y^{\prime}, \mu^{\prime}\right| T^{*}|x y, \mu\rangle\left\langle x y \mid q_{x} q_{y}\right\rangle=\left\langle\mu^{\prime}\right| T^{*}(\mathbf{q})|\mu\rangle\left\langle x^{\prime} y^{\prime} \mid q_{x} q_{y}\right\rangle \tag{7.68} \end{equation*}xy∑​⟨x′y′,μ′∣T∗∣xy,μ⟩⟨xy∣qx​qy​⟩=⟨μ′∣T∗(q)∣μ⟩⟨x′y′∣qx​qy​⟩​(7.68)​

Each 4×44 \times 44×4 block is labeled by a wavevector q=(qx,qy)\mathbf{q}=\left(q_{x}, q_{y}\right)q=(qx​,qy​), and takes the form

T∗(q)=[e−iqxe−i(qx−π4)0e−i(qx+π4)e−i(qy+π4)e−iqye−i(qy−π4)00ei(qx−π4)eiqxei(qx+π4)ei(qy+π4)0ei(qy−π4)eiqy](7.69)T^{*}(\mathbf{q})=\left[\begin{array}{cccc} \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} q_{x}} & \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i}\left(q_{x}-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} & 0 & \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i}\left(q_{x}+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} \tag{7.69}\\ \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i}\left(q_{y}+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} & \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} q_{y}} & \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i}\left(q_{y}-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} & 0 \\ 0 & \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}\left(q_{x}-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} & \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} q_{x}} & \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}\left(q_{x}+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} \\ \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}\left(q_{y}+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} & 0 & \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}\left(q_{y}-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} & \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} q_{y}} \end{array}\right]T∗(q)=​e−iqx​e−i(qy​+4π​)0ei(qy​+4π​)​e−i(qx​−4π​)e−iqy​ei(qx​−4π​)0​0e−i(qy​−4π​)eiqx​ei(qy​−4π​)​e−i(qx​+4π​)0ei(qx​+4π​)eiqy​​​(7.69)

To ensure that a path that starts at the origin completes a loop properly, the final arrival direction at the origin must coincide with the original one. Summing over all four such directions, the total number of such loops is obtained from

⟨0∣W∗(ℓ)∣0⟩=∑μ=14⟨00,μ∣T∗ℓ∣00,μ⟩=1N∑xy,μ⟨xy,μ∣T∗ℓ∣xy,μ⟩=1Ntr⁡(T∗ℓ).\begin{equation*} \langle\mathbf{0}| W^{*}(\ell)|\mathbf{0}\rangle=\sum_{\mu=1}^{4}\langle 00, \mu| T^{* \ell}|00, \mu\rangle=\frac{1}{N} \sum_{x y, \mu}\langle x y, \mu| T^{* \ell}|x y, \mu\rangle=\frac{1}{N} \operatorname{tr}\left(T^{* \ell}\right) . \tag{7.70} \end{equation*}⟨0∣W∗(ℓ)∣0⟩=μ=1∑4​⟨00,μ∣T∗ℓ∣00,μ⟩=N1​xy,μ∑​⟨xy,μ∣T∗ℓ∣xy,μ⟩=N1​tr(T∗ℓ).​(7.70)​

Using Eq. (7.58), the free energy is calculated as

ln⁡ZN=ln⁡(2cosh⁡2K)−12∑ℓtℓℓ⟨0∣W∗(ℓ)∣0⟩=ln⁡(2cosh⁡2K)−12Ntr⁡[∑ℓT∗ℓtℓℓ]=ln⁡(2cosh⁡2K)+12Ntr⁡ln⁡(1−tT∗)=ln⁡(2cosh⁡2K)+12N∑qtr⁡ln⁡(1−tT∗(q)).\begin{align*} \frac{\ln Z}{N} & =\ln \left(2 \cosh ^{2} K\right)-\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\ell} \frac{t^{\ell}}{\ell}\langle\mathbf{0}| W^{*}(\ell)|\mathbf{0}\rangle=\ln \left(2 \cosh ^{2} K\right)-\frac{1}{2 N} \operatorname{tr}\left[\sum_{\ell} \frac{T^{* \ell} t^{\ell}}{\ell}\right] \\ & =\ln \left(2 \cosh ^{2} K\right)+\frac{1}{2 N} \operatorname{tr} \ln \left(1-t T^{*}\right) \tag{7.71}\\ & =\ln \left(2 \cosh ^{2} K\right)+\frac{1}{2 N} \sum_{\mathbf{q}} \operatorname{tr} \ln \left(1-t T^{*}(\mathbf{q})\right) . \end{align*}NlnZ​​=ln(2cosh2K)−21​ℓ∑​ℓtℓ​⟨0∣W∗(ℓ)∣0⟩=ln(2cosh2K)−2N1​tr[ℓ∑​ℓT∗ℓtℓ​]=ln(2cosh2K)+2N1​trln(1−tT∗)=ln(2cosh2K)+2N1​q∑​trln(1−tT∗(q)).​(7.71)​

But for any matrix MMM with eigenvalues {λα}\left\{\lambda_{\alpha}\right\}{λα​},

tr⁡ln⁡M=∑αln⁡λα=ln⁡∏αλα=ln⁡det⁡M.\operatorname{tr} \ln M=\sum_{\alpha} \ln \lambda_{\alpha}=\ln \prod_{\alpha} \lambda_{\alpha}=\ln \operatorname{det} M .trlnM=α∑​lnλα​=lnα∏​λα​=lndetM.

Converting the sum over q\mathbf{q}q in Eq. (7.71) to an integral leads to

ln⁡ZN=ln⁡(2cosh⁡2K)+12∫ d2q(2π)2ln⁡{det⁡∣1−te−iqx−te−i(qx−π4)0−te−i(qx+π4)−te−i(qy+π4)1−te−iqy−te−i(qy−π4)00−tei(qx−π4)1−teiqx−tei(qx+π4)−tei(qy+π4)0−tei(qy−π4)1−teiqy∣}.\begin{align*} \frac{\ln Z}{N}= & \ln \left(2 \cosh ^{2} K\right)+\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{2}} \\ & \ln \left\{\operatorname{det}\left|\begin{array}{cccc} 1-t \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} q_{x}} & -t \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i}\left(q_{x}-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} & 0 & -t \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i}\left(q_{x}+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} \\ -t \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i}\left(q_{y}+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} & 1-t \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} q_{y}} & -t \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i}\left(q_{y}-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} & 0 \\ 0 & -\mathrm{te}^{\mathrm{i}\left(q_{x}-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} & 1-t \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} q_{x}} & -t \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}\left(q_{x}+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} \\ -t \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}\left(q_{y}+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} & 0 & -t \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}\left(q_{y}-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)} & 1-t \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} q_{y}} \end{array}\right|\right\} . \tag{7.72} \end{align*}NlnZ​=​ln(2cosh2K)+21​∫(2π)2 d2q​ln⎩⎨⎧​det​1−te−iqx​−te−i(qy​+4π​)0−tei(qy​+4π​)​−te−i(qx​−4π​)1−te−iqy​−tei(qx​−4π​)0​0−te−i(qy​−4π​)1−teiqx​−tei(qy​−4π​)​−te−i(qx​+4π​)0−tei(qx​+4π​)1−teiqy​​​⎭⎬⎫​.​(7.72)​

Evaluation of the above determinant is straightforward, and the final result is

ln⁡ZN=ln⁡(2cosh⁡2K)+12∫ d2q(2π)2ln⁡[(1+t2)2−2t(1−t2)(cos⁡qx+cos⁡qy)]\begin{equation*} \frac{\ln Z}{N}=\ln \left(2 \cosh ^{2} K\right)+\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{2}} \ln \left[\left(1+t^{2}\right)^{2}-2 t\left(1-t^{2}\right)\left(\cos q_{x}+\cos q_{y}\right)\right] \tag{7.73} \end{equation*}NlnZ​=ln(2cosh2K)+21​∫(2π)2 d2q​ln[(1+t2)2−2t(1−t2)(cosqx​+cosqy​)]​(7.73)​

Taking advantage of trigonometric identities, the result can be simplified to

ln⁡ZN=ln⁡2+12∫−ππdqx dqy(2π)2ln⁡[cosh⁡2(2K)−sinh⁡(2K)(cos⁡qx+cos⁡qy)]\begin{equation*} \frac{\ln Z}{N}=\ln 2+\frac{1}{2} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \frac{\mathrm{d} q_{x} \mathrm{~d} q_{y}}{(2 \pi)^{2}} \ln \left[\cosh ^{2}(2 K)-\sinh (2 K)\left(\cos q_{x}+\cos q_{y}\right)\right] \tag{7.74} \end{equation*}NlnZ​=ln2+21​∫−ππ​(2π)2dqx​ dqy​​ln[cosh2(2K)−sinh(2K)(cosqx​+cosqy​)]​(7.74)​

While it is possible to obtain a closed form expression by performing the integrals exactly, the final expression involves a hypergeometric function, and is not any more illuminating.

7.8 Critical behavior of the two-dimensional Ising model

To understand the singularity in the free energy of the two-dimensional Ising model in Eq. (7.73), we start with the simpler expression obtained by the unrestricted sum over phantom loops in Section 7.6. Specializing Eq. (7.53) to d=2d=2d=2,

fG=ln⁡(2cosh⁡2K)−12∫ dqx dqy(2π)2ln⁡[1−2t(cos⁡qx+cos⁡qy)].\begin{equation*} f_{G}=\ln \left(2 \cosh ^{2} K\right)-\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d} q_{x} \mathrm{~d} q_{y}}{(2 \pi)^{2}} \ln \left[1-2 t\left(\cos q_{x}+\cos q_{y}\right)\right] . \tag{7.75} \end{equation*}fG​=ln(2cosh2K)−21​∫(2π)2 dqx​ dqy​​ln[1−2t(cosqx​+cosqy​)].​(7.75)​

Apart from the argument of the logarithm, this expression is similar to the exact result. Is it possible that such similar functional forms lead to distinct singular behaviors? The singularity results from the vanishing of the argument of the logarithm at tc=1/4t_{c}=1 / 4tc​=1/4. In the vicinity of this point we make an expansion as in Eq. (7.50),

AG(t,q)=(1−4t)+tq2+O(q4)≈tc(q2+4δttc),\begin{equation*} A_{G}(t, \mathbf{q})=(1-4 t)+t q^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(q^{4}\right) \approx t_{c}\left(q^{2}+4 \frac{\delta t}{t_{c}}\right), \tag{7.76} \end{equation*}AG​(t,q)=(1−4t)+tq2+O(q4)≈tc​(q2+4tc​δt​),​(7.76)​

where δt=tc−t\delta t=t_{c}-tδt=tc​−t. The singular part of Eq. (7.75) can be obtained by focusing on the behavior of the integrand as q→0\mathbf{q} \rightarrow \mathbf{0}q→0, and replacing the square Brillouin zone for the range of the integral with a circle of radius Λ≈2π\Lambda \approx 2 \piΛ≈2π,

fsing =−12∫0Λ2πq dq4π2ln⁡(q2+4δttc)=−18π[(q2+4δttc)ln⁡(q2+4δt/tce)]0Λ\begin{align*} f_{\text {sing }} & =-\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\Lambda} \frac{2 \pi q \mathrm{~d} q}{4 \pi^{2}} \ln \left(q^{2}+4 \frac{\delta t}{t_{c}}\right) \\ & =-\frac{1}{8 \pi}\left[\left(q^{2}+4 \frac{\delta t}{t_{c}}\right) \ln \left(\frac{q^{2}+4 \delta t / t_{c}}{e}\right)\right]_{0}^{\Lambda} \tag{7.77} \end{align*}fsing ​​=−21​∫0Λ​4π22πq dq​ln(q2+4tc​δt​)=−8π1​[(q2+4tc​δt​)ln(eq2+4δt/tc​​)]0Λ​​(7.77)​

Only the expression evaluated at q=0q=0q=0 is singular, and

fsing=12π(δttc)ln⁡(δttc)\begin{equation*} f_{\mathrm{sing}}=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\left(\frac{\delta t}{t_{c}}\right) \ln \left(\frac{\delta t}{t_{c}}\right) \tag{7.78} \end{equation*}fsing​=2π1​(tc​δt​)ln(tc​δt​)​(7.78)​

The resulting heat capacity, CG∝∂2fG/∂2tC_{G} \propto \partial^{2} f_{G} / \partial^{2} tCG​∝∂2fG​/∂2t, diverges as 1/δt1 / \delta t1/δt. Since Eq. (7.75) is not valid for t>tct>t_{c}t>tc​, we cannot obtain the behavior of heat capacity on the low-temperature side.

For the exact result of Eq. (7.73), the argument of the logarithm is

A∗(t,q)=(1+t2)2−2t(1−t2)(cos⁡qx+cos⁡qy)\begin{equation*} A^{*}(t, \mathbf{q})=\left(1+t^{2}\right)^{2}-2 t\left(1-t^{2}\right)\left(\cos q_{x}+\cos q_{y}\right) \tag{7.79} \end{equation*}A∗(t,q)=(1+t2)2−2t(1−t2)(cosqx​+cosqy​)​(7.79)​

The minimum value of this expression, for q=0\mathbf{q}=\mathbf{0}q=0, is

A∗(t,0)=(1+tc2)2−4tc(1−tc2)=(1−tc2)2+4tc2−4tc(1−tc2)=(1−tc2−2tc)2.\begin{equation*} A^{*}(t, \mathbf{0})=\left(1+t_{c}^{2}\right)^{2}-4 t_{c}\left(1-t_{c}^{2}\right)=\left(1-t_{c}^{2}\right)^{2}+4 t_{c}^{2}-4 t_{c}\left(1-t_{c}^{2}\right)=\left(1-t_{c}^{2}-2 t_{c}\right)^{2} . \tag{7.80} \end{equation*}A∗(t,0)=(1+tc2​)2−4tc​(1−tc2​)=(1−tc2​)2+4tc2​−4tc​(1−tc2​)=(1−tc2​−2tc​)2.​(7.80)​

Since this expression (and hence the argument of the logarithm) is always nonnegative, the integral exists for all values of ttt. As required, unlike Eq. (7.75), the exact result is valid at all temperatures. There is a singularity when the argument vanishes for

tc2+2tc−1=0,⟹tc=−1±2\begin{equation*} t_{c}^{2}+2 t_{c}-1=0, \quad \Longrightarrow \quad t_{c}=-1 \pm \sqrt{2} \tag{7.81} \end{equation*}tc2​+2tc​−1=0,⟹tc​=−1±2​​(7.81)​

The positive solution describes a ferromagnet, and leads to a value of Kc=K_{c}=Kc​= ln⁡(2+1)/2\ln (\sqrt{2}+1) / 2ln(2​+1)/2, in agreement with the duality arguments of Section 7.4. Setting δt=t−tc\delta t=t-t_{c}δt=t−tc​, and expanding Eq. (7.79) in the vicinity of q→0\mathbf{q} \rightarrow 0q→0 gives

A∗(t,q)≈[(−2tc−2)δt]2+tc(1−tc2)q2+⋯≈2tc2[q2+4(δttc)2]\begin{align*} A^{*}(t, \mathbf{q}) & \approx\left[\left(-2 t_{c}-2\right) \delta t\right]^{2}+t_{c}\left(1-t_{c}^{2}\right) q^{2}+\cdots \\ & \approx 2 t_{c}^{2}\left[q^{2}+4\left(\frac{\delta t}{t_{c}}\right)^{2}\right] \tag{7.82} \end{align*}A∗(t,q)​≈[(−2tc​−2)δt]2+tc​(1−tc2​)q2+⋯≈2tc2​[q2+4(tc​δt​)2]​(7.82)​

The important difference from Eq. (7.76) is that (δt/tc)\left(\delta t / t_{c}\right)(δt/tc​) appears at quadratic order. Following the steps in Eqs. (7.77) and (7.78), the singular part of the free energy is

ln⁡ZN∣sing =12∫0Λ2πq dq4π2ln⁡[q2+4(δttc)2]=18π[(q2+4(δttc)2)ln⁡(q2+4(δt/tc)2e)]0Λ=−1π(δttc)2ln⁡∣δttc∣+ analytic terms. \begin{align*} \left.\frac{\ln Z}{N}\right|_{\text {sing }} & =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\Lambda} \frac{2 \pi q \mathrm{~d} q}{4 \pi^{2}} \ln \left[q^{2}+4\left(\frac{\delta t}{t_{c}}\right)^{2}\right] \\ & =\frac{1}{8 \pi}\left[\left(q^{2}+4\left(\frac{\delta t}{t_{c}}\right)^{2}\right) \ln \left(\frac{q^{2}+4\left(\delta t / t_{c}\right)^{2}}{e}\right)\right]_{0}^{\Lambda} \tag{7.83}\\ & =-\frac{1}{\pi}\left(\frac{\delta t}{t_{c}}\right)^{2} \ln \left|\frac{\delta t}{t_{c}}\right|+\text { analytic terms. } \end{align*}NlnZ​​sing ​​=21​∫0Λ​4π22πq dq​ln[q2+4(tc​δt​)2]=8π1​[(q2+4(tc​δt​)2)ln(eq2+4(δt/tc​)2​)]0Λ​=−π1​(tc​δt​)2ln​tc​δt​​+ analytic terms. ​(7.83)​

The heat capacity is obtained by taking two derivatives and diverges as C(δt)sing =A±ln⁡∣δt∣C(\delta t)_{\text {sing }}=A_{ \pm} \ln |\delta t|C(δt)sing ​=A±​ln∣δt∣. The logarithmic singularity corresponds to the limit α=\alpha=α= 0 ; the peak is symmetric, characterized by the amplitude ratio A+/A−=1A_{+} / A_{-}=1A+​/A−​=1.

The exact partition function of the Ising model on the square lattice was originally calculated by Lars Onsager in 1944 (Phys. Rev. 65, 117). Onsager used a 2L×2L2^{L} \times 2^{L}2L×2L transfer matrix to study a lattice of width LLL. He then identified various symmetries of this matrix which allowed him to diagonalize it and obtain the largest eigenvalue as a function of LLL. For any finite LLL, this eigenvalue is non-degenerate as required by Frobenius' theorem. In the limit L→∞L \rightarrow \inftyL→∞, the top two eigenvalues become degenerate at KcK_{c}Kc​. The result in this limit naturally coincides with Eq. (7.74). Onsager's paper is quite long and complicated, and regarded as a tour de force of mathematical physics. A somewhat streamlined version of this solution was developed by B. Kaufman (Phys. Rev. 76, 1232 (1949)). The exact solution, for the first time, demonstrated that critical behavior at a phase transition can in fact be quite different from predictions of Landau (mean-field) theory. It took almost three decades to reconcile the two results by the renormalization group.

The graphical method presented in this section was originally developed by Kac and Ward (Phys. Rev. 88, 1332 (1952)). The main ingredient of the derivation is the result that the correct accounting of the paths can be achieved by including a factor of (−1)(-1)(−1) for each intersection. (This conjecture by Feynman is proved in S. Sherman, J. Math. Phys. 1, 202 (1960).) The change of sign is reminiscent of the exchange factor between fermions. Indeed, Schultz, Mattis, and Lieb (Rev. Mod. Phys. 36, 856 (1964)) describe how the Onsager transfer matrix can be regarded as a Hamiltonian for the evolution of non-interacting fermions in one dimension. The Pauli exclusion principle prevents intersections of the world-lines of these fermions in two dimensional space-time.

In addition to the partition function, the correlation functions ⟨σiσj⟩\left\langle\sigma_{\mathbf{i}} \sigma_{\mathbf{j}}\right\rangle⟨σi​σj​⟩ can also be calculated by summing over paths. Since the combination q2+4(δt/tc)2q^{2}+4\left(\delta t / t_{c}\right)^{2}q2+4(δt/tc​)2 in Eq. (7.82) describes the behavior of these random walks, we expect a correlation length ξ∼∣tc/δt∣\xi \sim\left|t_{c} / \delta t\right|ξ∼∣tc​/δt∣, i.e. diverging with an exponent ν=1\nu=1ν=1 on both sides of the phase transition with an amplitude ratio of unity. The exponents α\alphaα and ν\nuν are related by the hyperscaling identity α=2−2ν\alpha=2-2 \nuα=2−2ν.
