The critical correlations at tct_{c}tc​ are more subtle and decay as ⟨σiσj⟩c∼1/∣i−j∣η\left\langle\sigma_{\mathbf{i}} \sigma_{j}\right\rangle_{c} \sim 1 /|\mathbf{i}-\mathbf{j}|^{\eta}⟨σi​σj​⟩c​∼1/∣i−j∣η, with η=1/4\eta=1 / 4η=1/4. Integrating the correlation functions yields the susceptibility, which diverges as χ±≃C±∣δt∣−γ\chi_{ \pm} \simeq C_{ \pm}|\delta t|^{-\gamma}χ±​≃C±​∣δt∣−γ, with γ=7/4\gamma=7 / 4γ=7/4, and C+/C−=1C_{+} / C_{-}=1C+​/C−​=1. A rather simple expression for the zero field magnetization,

m=(1−sinh⁡−4(2K))1/8,\begin{equation*} m=\left(1-\sinh ^{-4}(2 K)\right)^{1 / 8}, \tag{7.84} \end{equation*}m=(1−sinh−4(2K))1/8,​(7.84)​

was presented without proof by Onsager. A rather difficult derivation of this result was finally given by C.N. Yang (Phys. Rev. 85, 808 (1952)). The exponent β=1/8\beta=1 / 8β=1/8 satisfies the required exponent identities.

  1. Triangular/hexagonal lattices: For any planar network of bonds, one can define a geometrical dual by connecting the centers of neighboring plaquettes. βH~=∑pJ~(n12p−n23p+n34p−n41p),\widetilde{\beta \mathcal{H}}=\sum_{p} \widetilde{J}\left(n_{12}^{p}-n_{23}^{p}+n_{34}^{p}-n_{41}^{p}\right),βH​=p∑​J(n12p​−n23p​+n34p​−n41p​),

(e) Consider a Potts gauge theory defined on the plaquettes of a four-dimensional hypercubic lattice. Find its critical coupling Jc(q)J_{c}(q)Jc​(q).

Percolation

Fluids do not pass through a solid with a small concentration of holes. However, beyond a threshold concentration, the holes overlap, and the fluid can percolate through a connected channel in the material. Percolation is a classical geometric phase transition, and has been used as a model of many breakdown or failure processes. The loss of rigidity in an elastic network, conductivity in resistor nets, and magnetization in diluted magnets are but a few examples.

In simple models of percolation, elements of a lattice (sites or bonds) are independently occupied with a probability ppp. A cluster is defined as a connected (by neighboring bonds) set of these occupied elements. At small ppp, only small clusters exist, and the probability that two sites, separated by a distance rrr, are connected to each other decays as exp⁡(−r/ξ)\exp (-r / \xi)exp(−r/ξ). The correlation length ξ(p)\xi(p)ξ(p) grows with increasing ppp, diverging at the percolation threshold pcp_{c}pc​ as ξ(p)∼∣pc−p∣−ν\xi(p) \sim\left|p_{c}-p\right|^{-\nu}ξ(p)∼∣pc​−p∣−ν. An infinite cluster first appears at this threshold, and percolates through the (infinite) system for all p>pcp>p_{c}p>pc​. The analog of the order parameter is the probability P(p)P(p)P(p) that a site belongs to this infinite cluster. On approaching pcp_{c}pc​ from above, it vanishes as P(p)∼∣pc−p∣βP(p) \sim\left|p_{c}-p\right|^{\beta}P(p)∼∣pc​−p∣β. While the value of pcp_{c}pc​ depends on the details of the model, the exponents β\betaβ and ν\nuν are universal, varying only with the spatial dimension ddd.

In the following problems we shall focus on bond percolation, i.e. ppp denotes the probability that a bond on the lattice is occupied.

  1. Cayley trees: Consider a hierarchical lattice in which each site at one level is connected to zzz sites at the level below. Thus the nnn-th level of the tree has znz^{n}zn sites. (a) For z=2z=2z=2, obtain a recursion relation for the probability Pn(p)P_{n}(p)Pn​(p) that the top site of a tree of nnn levels is connected to some site at the bottom level. (b) Find the limiting behavior of P(p)P(p)P(p) for infinitely many levels, and give the exponent β\betaβ for this tree. (c) In a mean-field approximation, P(p)P(p)P(p) for a lattice of coordination number zzz is calculated self-consistently, in a manner similar to the above. Give the mean-field estimates for pcp_{c}pc​ and the exponent β\betaβ. (d) The one-dimensional chain corresponds to z=1z=1z=1. Find the probability that endpoints of an open chain of N+1N+1N+1 sites are connected, and hence deduce the correlation length ξ\xiξ.
  2. Duality has a very natural interpretation in percolation: If a bond is occupied, its dual is empty, and vice versa. Thus the occupation probability for dual bonds is p~=1−p≡q\widetilde{p}=1-p \equiv qp​=1−p≡q. Since, by construction, the original and dual elements do not intersect, one or the other percolates through the system. (a) The dual of a chain in which NNN bonds are connected in series has NNN bonds connected in parallel. What is the corresponding (non-) percolation probability? (b) The bond percolation problem on a square lattice is self-dual. What is its threshold pcp_{c}pc​ ? (c) Bond percolation in three dimensions is dual to plaquette percolation. This is why in d=3d=3d=3 it is possible to percolate while maintaining solid integrity. (d) The triangular and hexagonal lattices are dual to each other. Combined with the star-triangle transformation that also maps the two lattices, this leads to exact values of pcp_{c}pc​ for these lattices. However, this calculation is not trivial, and it is best to follow the steps for calculations of the critical couplings of qqq-state Potts models in an earlier problem.
  3. Position-space renormalization group (PSRG): In the Migdal-Kadanoff approximation, a decimation is performed after bonds are moved to connect the remaining sites in a one-dimensional geometry. For a PSRG rescaling factor bbb on a ddd-dimensional hypercubic lattice, the retained sites are connected by bd−1b^{d-1}bd−1 strands in parallel, each strand having bbb bonds in series. This scheme is naturally exact for d=1d=1d=1, and becomes progressively worse in higher dimensions. (a) Apply the above scheme to b=d=2b=d=2b=d=2, and compare the resulting estimates of pcp_{c}pc​ and yt=1/νy_{t}=1 / \nuyt​=1/ν to the exact values for the square lattice ( pc=1/2p_{c}=1 / 2pc​=1/2 and yt=3/4y_{t}=3 / 4yt​=3/4 ). (b) Find the limiting values of pcp_{c}pc​ and yty_{t}yt​ for large ddd. (It can be shown that ν=1/2\nu=1 / 2ν=1/2 exactly, above an upper critical dimension du=6d_{u}=6du​=6.) (c) In an alternative PSRG scheme, first bd−1b^{d-1}bd−1 bonds are connected in parallel, the resulting groups are then joined in series. Repeat the above calculations with this scheme.
